subparagraph.text: the party has received written notice or on the record notice before a judge of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the revocation provisions in subsections (a)(2) and (c)(1) of this section;
the search rights of adoptees and parents under § 5-359 of this subtitle and the search rights of adoptees, parents, and siblings under Subtitle 4B of this title; and
the right to file a disclosure veto under § 5-359 of this subtitle;

subparagraph.text: if signed after counsel enters an appearance for a parent, the consent is accompanied by an affidavit of counsel stating that:

sub-subparagraph.text: counsel reviewed the consent with the parent; and
the parent consents knowingly and voluntarily; and

subparagraph.text: the consent is accompanied by an affidavit of counsel appointed under § 5-307(a) of this subtitle stating that a parent who is a minor or has a disability consents knowingly and voluntarily.

paragraph.text: Whenever a local department receives consent to guardianship of an individual before a guardianship petition is filed, the local department promptly shall:

subparagraph.text: file the consent in the individual’s CINA case; and
serve a copy of the consent on:

sub-subparagraph.text: each living parent of the individual;
the parent’s last attorney of record in the CINA case; and
the individual’s last attorney of record in the CINA case.

paragraph.text: Whenever a party obtains consent to guardianship after a guardianship petition is filed, the party promptly shall:

subparagraph.text: file the consent with the juvenile court in which the petition is pending; and
serve a copy of the consent on each other party.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a person may revoke consent to guardianship any time within the later of:

subparagraph.text: 30 days after the person signs the consent; or
30 days after the consent is filed as required under this section.

paragraph.text: Consent to guardianship under subsection (a)(2) of this section is irrevocable.

subsection.text: If, at any time before a juvenile court enters an order for adoption of a child, the juvenile court finds that a condition of consent to guardianship will not be fulfilled, the consent or acquiescence becomes invalid.
If all consents for guardianship of a child have been given in accordance with this subtitle and the child has not objected, a juvenile court may enter an order for guardianship.

paragraph.text: Within 5 days after entry of an order under this section, a juvenile court shall give notice of the order to:

subparagraph.text: each party or, if represented, counsel;
each of the child’s living parents who has not waived the right to notice;
each living parent’s last attorney of record in the CINA case; and
the child’s last attorney of record in the CINA case.

paragraph.text: Notice under this subsection shall be by first-class mail.
Notice to a party under this subsection shall be sent to the party’s last address known to the juvenile court.

subsection.text: In this section, “drug” means cocaine, heroin, methamphetamine, or a derivative of cocaine, heroin, or methamphetamine.

If, after consideration of factors as required in this section, a juvenile court finds by clear and convincing evidence that a parent is unfit to remain in a parental relationship with the child or that exceptional circumstances exist that would make a continuation of the parental relationship detrimental to the best interests of the child such that terminating the rights of the parent is in a child’s best interests, the juvenile court may grant guardianship of the child without consent otherwise required under this subtitle and over the child’s objection.

A juvenile court need not consider any factor listed in subsection (d) of this section in determining a child’s best interests if, after a thorough investigation by a local department, the juvenile court finds that:

paragraph.text: the identities of the child’s parents are unknown; and
during the 60 days immediately after the child’s adjudication as a child in need of assistance, no one has claimed to be the child’s parent.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, in ruling on a petition for guardianship of a child, a juvenile court shall give primary consideration to the health and safety of the child and consideration to all other factors needed to determine whether terminating a parent’s rights is in the child’s best interests, including:

subparagraph.text: all services offered to the parent before the child’s placement, whether offered by a local department, another agency, or a professional;
the extent, nature, and timeliness of services offered by a local department to facilitate reunion of the child and parent; and
the extent to which a local department and parent have fulfilled their obligations under a social services agreement, if any;

paragraph.text: the results of the parent’s effort to adjust the parent’s circumstances, condition, or conduct to make it in the child’s best interests for the child to be returned to the parent’s home, including:

subparagraph.text: the extent to which the parent has maintained regular contact with:

sub-subparagraph.text: the child;
the local department to which the child is committed; and
if feasible, the child’s caregiver;

subparagraph.text: the parent’s contribution to a reasonable part of the child’s care and support, if the parent is financially able to do so;
the existence of a parental disability that makes the parent consistently unable to care for the child’s immediate and ongoing physical or psychological needs for long periods of time; and

whether additional services would be likely to bring about a lasting parental adjustment so that the child could be returned to the parent within an ascertainable time not to exceed 18 months from the date of placement unless the juvenile court makes a specific finding that it is in the child’s best interests to extend the time for a specified period;

paragraph.text: whether:

subparagraph.text: the parent has abused or neglected the child or a minor and the seriousness of the abuse or neglect;

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: on admission to a hospital for the child’s delivery, the mother tested positive for a drug as evidenced by a positive toxicology test; or
upon the birth of the child, the child tested positive for a drug as evidenced by a positive toxicology test; and

sub-subparagraph.text: the mother refused the level of drug treatment recommended by a qualified addictions specialist, as defined in § 5–1201 of this title, or by a physician or psychologist, as defined in the Health Occupations Article;

subparagraph.text: the parent subjected the child to:

sub-subparagraph.text: chronic abuse;
chronic and life–threatening neglect;
sexual abuse; or
torture;

subparagraph.text: the parent has been convicted, in any state or any court of the United States, of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a crime of violence against:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: a minor offspring of the parent;
the child; or
another parent of the child; or

sub-subparagraph.text: aiding or abetting, conspiring, or soliciting to commit a crime described in item 1 of this item; and

subparagraph.text: the parent has involuntarily lost parental rights to a sibling of the child; and
the child’s emotional ties with and feelings toward the child’s parents, the child’s siblings, and others who may affect the child’s best interests significantly;
the child’s adjustment to:

sub-subparagraph.text: community;
home;
placement; and
school;

subparagraph.text: the child’s feelings about severance of the parent–child relationship; and
the likely impact of terminating parental rights on the child’s well–being.

paragraph.text: A juvenile court shall consider the evidence under subsection (d)(3)(i) and (ii) of this section as to a continuing or serious act or condition and may waive a local department’s obligations for services described in subsection (d)(1) of this section if, after appropriate evaluation of efforts made and services offered, the juvenile court finds by clear and convincing evidence that a waiver is in the child’s best interests.

A juvenile court may waive a local department’s obligations for services described in subsection (d)(1) of this section if the juvenile court finds by clear and convincing evidence that one or more of the acts or circumstances listed in subsection (d)(3)(iii), (iv), or (v) of this section exists.
If a juvenile court waives reunification efforts under § 3–812(d) of the Courts Article, the juvenile court may not consider any factor under subsection (d)(1) of this section.

subsection.text: If a juvenile court finds that an act or circumstance listed in subsection (d)(3)(iii), (iv), or (v) of this section exists, the juvenile court shall make a specific finding, based on facts in the record, whether return of the child to a parent’s custody poses an unacceptable risk to the child’s future safety.
If a parent has consented to guardianship in accordance with § 5–320(a)(1)(iii)1 of this subtitle, the loss of parental rights shall be considered voluntary.
In a separate order accompanying an order denying guardianship of a child, a juvenile court shall include:

paragraph.text: a specific factual finding on whether reasonable efforts have been made to finalize the child’s permanency plan;
any order under Title 3, Subtitle 8 of the Courts Article in the child’s best interests; and
a date, no later than 180 days after the date of the order, for the next review hearing under Title 3, Subtitle 8 of the Courts Article.
In a separate order accompanying an order granting guardianship of a child, a juvenile court:

subparagraph.text: shall include a directive terminating the child’s CINA case;
consistent with the child’s best interests:

sub-subparagraph.text: may place the child:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, in a specific type of facility; or
with a specific individual;

sub-subparagraph.text: may direct provision of services by a local department to:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the child; or
the child’s caregiver;

sub-subparagraph.text: subject to a local department retaining legal guardianship, may award to a caregiver limited authority to make an emergency or ordinary decision as to the child’s care, education, mental or physical health, or welfare;
may allow access to a medical or other record of the child;
may allow visitation for the child with a specific individual;
may appoint, or continue the appointment of, a court-appointed special advocate for any purpose set forth under § 3-830 of the Courts Article;
shall direct the provision of any other service or taking of any other action as to the child’s education, health, and welfare, including:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: for a child who is at least 16 years old, services needed to help the child’s transition from guardianship to independence; or
for a child with a disability, services to obtain ongoing care, if any, needed after the guardianship case ends; and

sub-subparagraph.text: may co-commit the child to the custody of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene and order the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene to provide a plan for the child of clinically appropriate services in the least restrictive setting, in accordance with federal and State law;

subparagraph.text: if entered under § 5-322 of this subtitle, shall state each party’s response to the petition;
shall state a specific factual finding on whether reasonable efforts have been made to finalize the child’s permanency plan;
shall state whether the child’s parent has waived the right to notice; and
shall set a date, no later than 180 days after the date of the order, for the initial guardianship review hearing under § 5-326 of this subtitle.

Except for emergency commitment in accordance with § 10-617 of the Health - General Article or as expressly authorized by a juvenile court in accordance with the standards in § 3-819(h) or (i) of the Courts Article, a child may not be committed or otherwise placed for inpatient care or treatment in a psychiatric facility or a facility for the developmentally disabled.
A juvenile court shall include in a commitment order under this paragraph a requirement that the guardian:

sub-subparagraph.text: file a progress report with the juvenile court at least every 180 days; and
provide a copy of each report to each person entitled to notice of a review hearing under § 5-326 of this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: Every 180 days during a commitment or placement under this paragraph, a juvenile court shall hold a hearing to determine whether the standards in § 3-819(h) or (i) of the Courts Article continue to be met.

subsection.text: A juvenile court shall send a copy of an order entered under this section to:

paragraph.text: each party or, if represented, counsel;
each of the child’s living parents who has not waived the right to notice;
each living parent’s last attorney of record in the CINA case; and
the child’s last attorney of record in the CINA case.

subsection.text: An order for guardianship of an individual:

paragraph.text: except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, § 4-414 of the Estates and Trusts Article, and § 2-123 of the Real Property Article, terminates a parent’s duties, obligations, and rights toward the individual;
eliminates the need for a further consent by a parent to adoption of the individual;
grants a local department guardianship with the right to consent to the individual’s adoption or other planned permanent living arrangement; and
terminates the individual’s CINA case.
Unless a juvenile court gives legal custody to another person, a child’s guardian under this subtitle has legal custody.

subparagraph.text: Unless a juvenile court orders otherwise and subject to review by the juvenile court, a child’s guardian may make all decisions affecting the child’s education, health, and welfare, including consenting:

sub-subparagraph.text: to adoption of the child;
to application by the child for a driver’s license;
to enlistment by the child in the armed forces;
to marriage of the child; and
subject to subparagraphs (ii) and (iii) of this paragraph, to medical, psychiatric, or surgical treatment.

subparagraph.text: A child’s guardian:

sub-subparagraph.text: may have the child admitted to an inpatient psychiatric facility in accordance with the standards for emergency commitment in § 10-617 of the Health - General Article for not more than 20 days;
except as provided in item 1 of this subparagraph, may not place the child in an inpatient psychiatric facility without express authorization of the juvenile court.
A child’s guardian may not withhold or withdraw a life-sustaining procedure without the prior authorization of a juvenile court.
In deciding whether to grant authorization, a juvenile court shall apply the factors set forth in § 13-711(b) of the Estates and Trusts Article.

paragraph.text: A local department shall notify a juvenile court, a child’s attorney, and the attorney for each other party who has not waived the right to notice:

subparagraph.text: within 2 business days after the child’s placement changes or the time required under § 5-326(b) of this subtitle, whichever is shorter;
within 2 business days after the child is placed in a psychiatric facility; or
within 2 business days after the child is absent from a placement for more than a week.

paragraph.text: A local department shall give a child’s attorney the child’s new address and telephone number within 2 business days after the address or telephone number changes.
A juvenile court shall hold:

subparagraph.text: an initial guardianship review hearing as scheduled under § 5-324(b)(1)(vi) of this subtitle to establish a permanency plan for the child; and
at least once each year after the initial guardianship review hearing until the juvenile court’s jurisdiction terminates, a guardianship review hearing.

paragraph.text: At each guardianship review hearing, a juvenile court shall determine whether:

subparagraph.text: the child’s current circumstances and placement are in the child’s best interests;
the permanency plan that is in effect is in the child’s best interests; and
reasonable efforts have been made to finalize the permanency plan that is in effect.
A juvenile court shall give at least 30 days’ notice before each guardianship review hearing for a child to:

sub-subparagraph.text: the local department;
the child’s attorney; and
each of the child’s living parents who has not waived the right to notice and that parent’s attorney.

subparagraph.text: A parent is entitled to be heard and to participate at a guardianship review hearing.
A parent is not a party solely on the basis of the right to notice or opportunity to be heard or participate at a guardianship review hearing.
A local department shall give a child’s caregiver at least 7 days’ notice before a guardianship review hearing.
A caregiver is entitled to be heard at a guardianship review hearing.
A caregiver is not a party solely on the basis of the right to notice or opportunity to be heard at a guardianship review hearing.
At least 10 days before each guardianship review hearing, a local department shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: investigate as needed to prepare a written report that summarizes the child’s circumstances and the progress that has been made in implementing the child’s permanency plan; and
send a copy of the report to:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the child’s attorney; and
each of the child’s living parents who has not waived the right to notice and that parent’s attorney.

subparagraph.text: Notice to a parent under this paragraph shall be sent to the parent’s last address known to the juvenile court.

paragraph.text: A child’s permanency plan may be, in order of priority:

subparagraph.text: adoption of the child;
custody and guardianship of the child by an individual; or
another planned permanent living arrangement that:

sub-subparagraph.text: addresses the individualized needs of the child, including the child’s educational plan, emotional stability, physical placement, and socialization needs; and
includes goals that promote the continuity of relations with individuals who will fill a lasting and significant role in the child’s life.

paragraph.text: Every reasonable effort shall be made to implement a permanency plan within 1 year.
At each guardianship review hearing for a child, a juvenile court shall:

subparagraph.text: evaluate the child’s safety and act as needed to protect the child;
consider the written report of a local out-of-home placement review board required under § 5-545 of this title;
determine the extent of compliance with the permanency plan;
make a specific factual finding on whether reasonable efforts have been made to finalize the child’s permanency plan and document the finding;
subject to subsection (b) of this section, change the child’s permanency plan if a change would be in the child’s best interests;
project a reasonable date by which the permanency plan will be finalized;
enter any order that the juvenile court finds appropriate to implement the permanency plan; and
take all other action that the juvenile court considers to be in the child’s best interests, including any order allowed under § 5-324(b)(1)(ii) of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: A juvenile court may approve a permanency plan other than adoption of a child only if the juvenile court finds that, for a compelling reason, adoption is not in the child’s best interests.

subparagraph.text: At a guardianship review hearing held 1 year or more after a juvenile court enters an order for guardianship of a child, the juvenile court may designate an individual guardian of the child if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the local department certifies the child’s successful placement with the individual under the supervision of the local department or its agent for at least 180 days or a shorter period allowed by the juvenile court on recommendation of the local department;
the local department files a report by a child placement agency, completed in accordance with department regulations, as to the suitability of the individual to be the child’s guardian; and
the juvenile court makes a specific finding that:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: for a compelling reason, adoption is not in the child’s best interests; and
custody and guardianship by the individual is in the child’s best interests and is the least restrictive alternative available.

subparagraph.text: Designation of a guardian under this paragraph terminates the local department’s legal obligations and responsibilities to the child.
After designation of a guardian under this paragraph, a juvenile court may order any further review that the juvenile court finds to be in the child’s best interests.

paragraph.text: Whenever a juvenile court orders a specific placement for a child, a local department may remove the child from the placement before a hearing only if:

subparagraph.text: removal is needed to protect the child from serious immediate danger;
continuation of the placement is contrary to the child’s best interests; or
the child’s caregiver asks for the child’s immediate removal.
On the next day on which the circuit court sits after a local department changes a placement under this subsection, the juvenile court shall hold an emergency review hearing on the change.
A juvenile court shall give reasonable notice of an emergency review hearing to:

sub-subparagraph.text: the child’s attorney;
each of the child’s living parents who has not waived the right to notice and that parent’s attorney; and
each other party’s attorney.

subparagraph.text: At an emergency review hearing, the standard of review as to a change shall be the standard for continued shelter care in a hearing under § 3-815 of the Courts Article.

Unless all of the parties agree to a juvenile court’s order entered at an emergency review hearing, the juvenile court shall hold a full review hearing on the change within 30 days after the date of removal or, if agreed to by the parties, a later date.

paragraph.text: At least every 12 months at a hearing under this section, the court shall consult on the record with the child in an age–appropriate manner to obtain the child’s views on permanency.

subparagraph.text: If, after a hearing or with the agreement of all parties, the court determines that the child is medically fragile and that it is detrimental to the child’s physical or mental health to be transported to the courthouse, the court may, subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph:

sub-subparagraph.text: visit the child at the child’s placement and use appropriate technology to document the consultation for the record; or
use video conferencing to consult with the child on the record during the hearing.

subparagraph.text: If the court visits the child at the child’s placement under subparagraph (i)1 of this paragraph or uses video conferencing under subparagraph (i)2 of this paragraph, the court shall give each party notice and an opportunity to attend the visit or the video conferencing, unless the court determines that it is not in the best interest of the child for a party to attend the visit or the video conferencing.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of paragraph (2)(ii) of this subsection, if the child’s placement is outside the State and, after a hearing or with the agreement of all parties, the court determines that it is not in the best interest of the child to be transported to the court, the court may use video conferencing to consult with the child on the record during the hearing.

section.text: If, after a juvenile court grants guardianship, a party becomes aware that a condition of consent to the guardianship may not be fulfilled:

paragraph.text: the party promptly shall:

subparagraph.text: file notice with the juvenile court;
give notice to all of the other parties; and
if consent was received from a governmental unit or person who is not a party, give notice to that unit or person;

paragraph.text: the juvenile court shall schedule a hearing to occur within 30 days after the filing of the notice; and
if the party, unit, or person whose condition cannot be fulfilled fails to enter into a new consent, the juvenile court shall:

subparagraph.text: set aside the guardianship order;
set the case in for a prompt trial on the merits of the guardianship petition; and
reopen the CINA case for review as required under Title 3, Subtitle 8 of the Courts Article.

subsection.text: If a local department is a child’s guardian under this subtitle, a juvenile court:

paragraph.text: retains jurisdiction until:

subparagraph.text: the child attains 18 years of age; or
the juvenile court finds the child to be eligible for emancipation; and

paragraph.text: may continue jurisdiction until the child attains 21 years of age.

subsection.text: If a juvenile court designates an individual as a child’s guardian, the juvenile court:

paragraph.text: may retain jurisdiction until the child attains 18 years of age; or
on finding further review unnecessary to maintain the child’s health and welfare, may terminate the case before the child attains 18 years of age.

subsection.text: An order for adoption of a child terminates the child’s guardianship case.
On termination of a guardianship case, a juvenile court shall close the case.
Before termination of parental rights as to a child, a petition for adoption of the child may be filed only as provided in this Part III of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: With the consent of the local department with custody of a child, any adult may petition a juvenile court under this Part III of this subtitle to adopt the child.
If a petitioner under this section is married, the petitioner’s spouse shall join in the petition unless the spouse:

subparagraph.text: is separated from the petitioner under a circumstance that gives the petitioner a ground for annulment or divorce; or
is not competent to join in the petition.

paragraph.text: A petitioner under this section shall attach to a petition:

subparagraph.text: for a parent who is dead, a death certificate;
for each other parent:

sub-subparagraph.text: the consent required under this Part III of this subtitle;
an affidavit, by the local department with custody of the child, stating that:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: despite reasonable efforts as provided in § 5-316 of this subtitle, the parent cannot be located; and
to the best knowledge of the local department, the parent has not contacted the local department or child for at least 180 days immediately before the filing of the petition; or

sub-subparagraph.text: if applicable:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: proof of guardianship or relinquishment of parental rights granted by an administrative, executive, or judicial body of a state or other jurisdiction; and
certification that the guardianship or relinquishment was granted in compliance with the jurisdiction’s laws;

subparagraph.text: each other consent required under § 5-338 of this subtitle;
a copy of an agreement, if any, for postadoption contact; and
a notice of filing that:

sub-subparagraph.text: states the date on which the petition was filed;
identifies each person whose consent was filed with the petition;
states the obligation of a parent to give the juvenile court and local department notice of each change in the parent’s address;
if applicable, states that a postadoption agreement was filed with the petition; and
includes no identifying information that would be in violation of an agreement or consent.

paragraph.text: In addition to a copy of an agreement for postadoption contact, a petitioner shall file the original agreement under seal.

subsection.text: If the marital status of a petitioner changes before entry of an order, the petitioner shall amend the petition accordingly.
The local department with custody of the child shall assist a petitioner in complying with the requirements of this section.

section.text: A clerk of a juvenile court shall keep a listing of each address given to the juvenile court for a parent under this Part III of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Within 5 days after a petition for adoption of a child is filed under this Part III of this subtitle with a juvenile court, the clerk shall send a copy of the petition, with the notice of filing that was attached to the petition, to:

paragraph.text: the local department with custody of the child;
each of the child’s living parents who has not waived the right to notice;
each living parent’s last attorney of record in the CINA case; and
the child’s last attorney of record in the CINA case.

subsection.text: Notice under this section shall be by first-class mail.
Notice to a parent under this section shall be sent to the parent’s last address known to the juvenile court.

Promptly after a petition for adoption is filed under this Part III of this subtitle, a juvenile court shall issue a show–cause order that requires the party to whom issued to respond as required under the Maryland Rules.
On issuance of a show–cause order as to adoption of a child under this section, a petitioner shall serve the order on:

paragraph.text: each of the child’s living parents who has not consented to the adoption;
each living parent’s last attorney of record in the CINA case; and
the child’s last attorney of record in the CINA case.

subsection.text: Service under this section shall be:

paragraph.text: on a parent, by:

subparagraph.text: first–class mail; and

sub-subparagraph.text: personal service; or
certified mail, restricted delivery, return receipt requested; and

paragraph.text: on an attorney, by:

subparagraph.text: personal service; or
certified mail, return receipt requested.

subsection.text: Service on a parent under this section shall be attempted as provided in § 5–316(d), (e), and (f) of this subtitle.
A juvenile court shall hold a hearing before entering an order for adoption under this Part III of this subtitle.
Before a hearing under this section, a juvenile court shall give notice to all of the parties.
Subject to subsection (b) of this section, a juvenile court shall rule on an adoption petition under this Part III of this subtitle promptly but no later than 180 days after the petition is filed.
A juvenile court may not enter an order for adoption of a child under this Part III of this subtitle before the later of:

paragraph.text: 30 days after the birth of the child;
expiration of the time set for revocation of consent, and not waived, under § 5–339 of this subtitle; or
expiration of the time to respond to show–cause orders issued under this subtitle.

subsection.text: In ruling on a petition for a child’s adoption under this Part III of this subtitle, a juvenile court shall consider:

paragraph.text: any assurance by a local department to fund needed support for the child;
all factors necessary to determine the child’s best interests; and
a report by a child placement agency, completed in accordance with Department regulations, as to:

subparagraph.text: the suitability of the petitioner to be the child’s parent; and

the child’s successful placement with the petitioner under the supervision of the local department or its agent for at least 180 days or a shorter period allowed by the juvenile court on recommendation of the local department.

subsection.text: In ruling on an adoption petition under this Part III of this subtitle, a juvenile court may not deny the petition solely because the petitioner is single or unmarried.
If a parent consents to adoption in accordance with § 5-338 of this subtitle, loss of parental rights shall be considered voluntary.
A juvenile court may enter an order for a child’s adoption under this Part III of this subtitle only if:

subparagraph.text: both the child’s parents are dead;

an administrative, executive, or judicial body of a state or other jurisdiction has granted a governmental unit or person other than a parent the power to consent to adoption, and the unit or person consents;
parental rights have been terminated in compliance with the laws of a state or other jurisdiction, as described in § 5–305 of this subtitle; or

sub-subparagraph.text: at least one of the child’s parents:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: is represented by an attorney;
has had an opportunity to receive adoption counseling and guidance services; and
consents to the adoption:
in writing; or
knowingly and voluntarily, on the record before the juvenile court; and

sub-subparagraph.text: the parent who does not consent:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: is dead; or
despite reasonable efforts as provided in § 5–316 of this subtitle, cannot be located;
has not contacted the local department with custody of the child or the child for at least 180 days immediately before the filing of the petition; and
fails to respond to a show–cause order served under § 5–334 of this subtitle;

paragraph.text: the director of the local department with custody of the child consents; and
the child:

subparagraph.text: is represented by an attorney; and

sub-subparagraph.text: if at least 10 years old, consents; or
if under the age of 10 years, does not object.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection, “disability” means:

sub-subparagraph.text: a physical disability, infirmity, malformation, or disfigurement that is caused by bodily injury, birth defect, or illness, including epilepsy;
a mental impairment or deficiency;
a record of having a physical or mental impairment as defined under this paragraph; or
being regarded as having a physical or mental impairment as defined under this paragraph.

subparagraph.text: “Disability” includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: any degree of paralysis or amputation;
blindness or visual impairment;
deafness or hearing impairment;
muteness or speech impediment;
physical reliance on a service animal or a wheelchair or other remedial appliance or device; and

intellectual disability, as defined in § 7–101 of the Health – General Article, and any other mental impairment or deficiency that may have necessitated remedial or special education and related services.

paragraph.text: A local department may not withhold consent for the sole reason that:

subparagraph.text: the race, religion, color, or national origin of a prospective adoptive parent differs from that of the child or parent; or
a prospective adoptive parent has a disability.

paragraph.text: Consent of a parent to an adoption under this Part III of this subtitle may include:

subparagraph.text: a provision barring a petitioner from learning identifying information about the parent; and
a waiver of the right to notice of further proceedings under this Part III of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Consent to adoption entered into before a judge on the record shall include a waiver of the revocation period.
Consent of a party to an adoption under this Part III of this subtitle is not valid unless:

subparagraph.text: the consent is given in a language that the party understands;
if given in a language other than English, the consent:

sub-subparagraph.text: is given before a judge on the record; or
is accompanied by the affidavit of a translator stating that the translation of the document of consent is accurate;

subparagraph.text: the consent names the child;
the consent contains enough information to identify the prospective adoptive parent;
the party has received written notice or on the record notice of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the revocation provisions in subsections (a)(2) and (b)(1) of this section;
the search rights of adoptees and parents under § 5-359 of this subtitle and the search rights of adoptees, parents, and siblings under Subtitle 4B of this title; and
the right to file a disclosure veto under § 5-359 of this subtitle; and

subparagraph.text: the consent is accompanied by an affidavit of counsel appointed under § 5-307(a) of this subtitle, stating that a parent who is a minor or has a disability consents knowingly and voluntarily.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a parent may revoke consent to adoption under this Part III of this subtitle at any time within the later of:

subparagraph.text: 30 days after the parent signs the consent; or
30 days after the adoption petition is filed.

paragraph.text: Consent to adoption under subsection (a)(2) of this section is irrevocable.

subsection.text: A local department may revoke consent to an adoption under this Part III of this subtitle at any time before a juvenile court enters an order of adoption under this Part III of this subtitle.
A child may revoke consent or object to an adoption under this Part III of this subtitle at any time before a juvenile court enters an order of adoption under this Part III of this subtitle.

section.text: If a petition for adoption under this Part III of this subtitle is contested, a juvenile court shall dismiss the petition.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not limit the right of an individual to provide for distribution of property by will.
Except as provided in § 2-123 of the Real Property Article, after a juvenile court enters an order for adoption under this Part III of this subtitle:

subparagraph.text: the adoptee:

sub-subparagraph.text: is the child of the adoptive parent for all intents and purposes; and
is entitled to all of the rights and privileges of and is subject to all of the obligations of offspring born to the adoptive parent;

subparagraph.text: each of the adoptee’s living parents is:

sub-subparagraph.text: relieved of all parental duties and obligations to the adoptee; and
divested of all parental rights as to the adoptee; and

subparagraph.text: the Estates and Trusts Article shall govern all of the rights of inheritance between the adoptee and parental relatives.

subsection.text: An order for adoption under this Part III of this subtitle terminates all pending CINA cases as to the adoptee.
Adoption of an adult has the same legal effect as adoption of a minor.

paragraph.text: When a juvenile court enters an order for a child’s adoption under this Part III of this subtitle, the juvenile court shall send notice to:

subparagraph.text: each juvenile court that has a pending CINA case as to the adoptee;
each of the child’s living, former parents who has not waived the right to notice;
each living parent’s last attorney of record in the CINA case; and
the child’s last attorney of record in the CINA case.

paragraph.text: Service on a parent under this subsection shall be at the parent’s last address known to the juvenile court.

section.text: If a petition to invalidate an order for adoption under this Part III of this subtitle on the basis of a jurisdictional or procedural defect is filed more than 1 year after entry of the order, a juvenile court shall dismiss the petition.

subsection.text: If, after termination of parental rights as to a child, there is an open guardianship case, a petition for adoption of the child may be filed only as provided in this Part IV of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Any adult may petition a juvenile court for an adoption under this Part IV of this subtitle.
If a petitioner under this section is married, the petitioner’s spouse shall join in the petition unless the spouse:

subparagraph.text: is separated from the petitioner under a circumstance that gives the petitioner a ground for annulment or divorce; or
is not competent to join in the petition.

paragraph.text: A petitioner under this section shall attach to a petition:

sub-subparagraph.text: all written consents required under § 5-350 of this subtitle; or
if applicable:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: proof of guardianship or relinquishment of parental rights granted by an administrative, executive, or judicial body of a state or other jurisdiction; and
certification that the guardianship or relinquishment was granted in compliance with the jurisdiction’s laws;

subparagraph.text: a copy of an agreement, if any, for postadoption contact; and
a notice of filing that:

sub-subparagraph.text: states the date on which the petition was filed;
identifies each governmental unit or person whose consent was filed with the petition;
if applicable, states that a postadoption agreement was filed with the petition; and
includes no identifying information that would be in violation of an agreement or consent.

paragraph.text: In addition to a copy of an agreement for postadoption contact, a petitioner shall file the original agreement under seal.

subsection.text: If the marital status of a petitioner changes before entry of an order, the petitioner shall amend the petition accordingly.

Within 5 days after a petition for adoption of a child is filed under this Part IV of this subtitle with a juvenile court, the clerk shall send a copy of the petition, with the notice of filing that was attached to the petition, to:

paragraph.text: the local department; and
the child’s last attorney of record in the guardianship case.

subsection.text: Notice under this section shall be by first-class mail.
A juvenile court shall hold a hearing before entering an order for adoption under this Part IV of this subtitle.
Before a hearing under this section, a juvenile court shall give notice to all of the parties.
Subject to subsection (b) of this section, a juvenile court shall rule on the adoption petition under this Part IV of this subtitle promptly but no later than 180 days after the petition is filed.
A juvenile court may not enter an order for adoption of a child under this Part IV of this subtitle before the later of:

paragraph.text: 30 days after the birth of the child; or
10 days after the notice is served under § 5-346 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In ruling on a petition for a child’s adoption under this Part IV of this subtitle, a juvenile court shall consider:

paragraph.text: any assurance by the local department to fund needed support for the child;
all factors necessary to determine the child’s best interests; and
a report by a child placement agency, completed in accordance with Department regulations, as to:

subparagraph.text: the suitability of the petitioner to be the child’s parent; and

the child’s successful placement for adoption with the petitioner under the supervision of the local department or its agent for at least 180 days or a shorter period allowed by the juvenile court on recommendation of the local department.

subsection.text: In ruling on a petition for adoption under this Part IV of this subtitle, a juvenile court may not deny a petition for adoption solely because the petitioner is single or unmarried.
A juvenile court may enter an order for a child’s adoption under this Part IV of this subtitle only if:

paragraph.text: for an individual under the age of 18 years, the individual’s guardian consents; and
for an individual who is at least 10 years old, the individual consents.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection, “disability” means:

sub-subparagraph.text: a physical disability, infirmity, malformation, or disfigurement that is caused by bodily injury, birth defect, or illness, including epilepsy;
a mental impairment or deficiency;
a record of having a physical or mental impairment as defined under this paragraph; or
being regarded as having a physical or mental impairment as defined under this paragraph.

subparagraph.text: “Disability” includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: any degree of paralysis or amputation;
blindness or visual impairment;
deafness or hearing impairment;
muteness or speech impediment;
physical reliance on a service animal or a wheelchair or other remedial appliance or device; and

intellectual disability, as defined in § 7–101 of the Health – General Article, and any other mental impairment or deficiency that may have necessitated remedial or special education and related services.

paragraph.text: A guardian may not withhold consent for the sole reason that:

subparagraph.text: the race, religion, color, or national origin of a prospective adoptive parent differs from that of the child or parent; or
a prospective adoptive parent has a disability.

subsection.text: Consent of a party to an adoption under this Part IV of this subtitle is not valid unless:

paragraph.text: the consent is given in a language that the party understands;
if given in a language other than English, the consent:

subparagraph.text: is given before a judge on the record; or
is accompanied by the affidavit of a translator stating that the translation of the document of consent is accurate;

paragraph.text: the consent names the child;
the consent contains enough information to identify the prospective adoptive parent; and
the party has received written notice or on-the-record notice of:

subparagraph.text: the revocation provisions in this section;
the search rights of adoptees and parents under § 5-359 of this subtitle and the search rights of adoptees, parents, and siblings under Subtitle 4B of this title; and
the right to file a disclosure veto under § 5-359 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A guardian may revoke consent to an adoption under this Part IV of this subtitle at any time before a juvenile court enters an order of adoption under this Part IV of this subtitle.
A child may revoke consent to an adoption under this Part IV of this subtitle at any time before a juvenile court enters an order of adoption under this Part IV of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not limit the right of an individual to provide for distribution of property by will.
Except as provided in § 2-123 of the Real Property Article, after a juvenile court enters an order for adoption under this Part IV of this subtitle:

subparagraph.text: the adoptee:

sub-subparagraph.text: is the child of the adoptive parent for all intents and purposes; and
is entitled to all of the rights and privileges of and is subject to all of the obligations of offspring born to the adoptive parent;

subparagraph.text: each of the adoptee’s living parents is:

sub-subparagraph.text: relieved of all parental duties and obligations to the adoptee; and
divested of all parental rights as to the adoptee; and

subparagraph.text: the Estates and Trusts Article shall govern all of the rights of inheritance between the adoptee and parental relatives.

subsection.text: An order for adoption under this Part IV of this subtitle terminates all pending guardianship cases as to the adoptee.
Adoption of an adult has the same legal effect as adoption of a minor.

paragraph.text: When a juvenile court enters an order for a child’s adoption under this Part IV of this subtitle, the juvenile court shall send notice to:

subparagraph.text: each juvenile court that has a pending guardianship case as to the adoptee;
each of the child’s living, former parents who has not waived the right to notice;
the former parent’s last attorney of record in the guardianship case; and
the child’s last attorney of record in the guardianship case.

paragraph.text: Service on a former parent under this subsection shall be at the parent’s last address known to the juvenile court.

section.text: If a petition to invalidate an order for adoption under this Part IV of this subtitle on the basis of a jurisdictional or procedural defect is filed more than 1 year after entry of the order, a juvenile court shall dismiss the petition.

subsection.text: A local department shall make reasonable efforts to compile and make available to a prospective adoptive parent:

paragraph.text: all of the prospective adoptee’s medical and mental health records that the local department has; or
a comprehensive medical and mental health history of the prospective adoptee.

subsection.text: On request of an adoptive or prospective adoptive parent, a local department shall make reasonable efforts to compile a pertinent medical and mental health history of each of the prospective adoptee’s or adoptee’s parents or former parents, if available to the local department, and to make the history available to the adoptive or prospective adoptive parent.

paragraph.text: If, after adoption, a local department receives medical or mental health information about the adoptee or adoptee’s former parent, the local department shall make reasonable efforts to make the information available to the adoptive parent.

If, after adoption, the adoptive parent requests additional information, the local department shall make reasonable efforts to notify the former parent, at the former parent’s last known address available to the local department, of the request and the reason for the request.

subsection.text: A medical or mental health history compiled under this section may not contain identifying information about a parent or former parent.

subparagraph.text: On request of an adoptee or adoptive or former parent of an adoptee and without a showing of a need, a local department shall provide information, other than identifying information, in its adoption record on the adoptee.

If a local department denies a request under this paragraph, then on petition of an adoptee or adoptive or former parent and without a showing of need, a juvenile court shall order access for the petitioner to inspect, in accordance with subsection (b) of this section, the local department’s record on the adoptee.

paragraph.text: On petition of an adoptee or adoptive or former parent of an adoptee and without a showing of need, a juvenile court shall order access for the petitioner to inspect, in accordance with subsection (b) of this section, the juvenile court’s record on the adoptee.

subsection.text: A juvenile court may not order opened for inspection under this section any part of a record that contains identifying information.

If, after a hearing on a petition of an adoptee or former parent, a juvenile court is satisfied that the adoptee or blood relative of the adoptee or former parent urgently needs medical information not in local department and juvenile court records, the juvenile court may appoint an intermediary to try to contact the adoptee or a former parent of the adoptee for the information.
An intermediary appointed under this section:

paragraph.text: may only advise an adoptee or former parent of the need for medical information; and
may not:

subparagraph.text: reveal any identifying information about an adoptee or former parent; or
try, in any manner, to encourage or discourage contact between an adoptee and former parent.

subsection.text: An intermediary appointed under this section shall file with the appointing juvenile court a confidential written report on the intermediary’s efforts to contact an adoptee or former parent.

When a juvenile court receives a report from an intermediary, the juvenile court may disclose to the adoptee or former parent, without revealing identifying information about an adoptee or former parent:

paragraph.text: whether the intermediary advised an adoptee or former parent about the need for medical information; and
medical information that the adoptee or a former parent provided.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a juvenile court may order an adoptee or former parent to pay a reasonable fee for the services of an intermediary under this section.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings stated.
“Director” means the State Director of Social Services.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene.

subsection.text: This section applies only to an adoption in which a juvenile court enters an order for adoption on or after January 1, 2000.
This section does not bar:

paragraph.text: an adoptee or biological parent from applying for search, contact, and reunion services under Subtitle 4B of this title; or
the Director or a confidential intermediary from obtaining a copy of a record under § 5-4B-04(c) or § 5-4B-06(b) or (c) of this title.
An adoptee who is at least 21 years old may apply to the Secretary for a copy of:

subparagraph.text: the adoptee’s original certificate of birth;
all records that relate to the adoptee’s new certificate of birth, if any; and
the report of the adoptee’s order of adoption filed by the clerk of court under § 4-211 of the Health - General Article.

paragraph.text: If an adoptee is at least 21 years old, a biological parent of the adoptee may apply to the Secretary for a copy of:

subparagraph.text: the adoptee’s original certificate of birth;
the new certificate of birth, if any, that was substituted, under § 4-211 of the Health - General Article, for the adoptee’s original certificate of birth;
all records that relate to the adoptee’s new certificate of birth; and
the report of the adoptee’s order of adoption filed by the clerk of court under § 4-211 of the Health - General Article.

paragraph.text: Each applicant under this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: provide all proof of identity and other relevant information that the Secretary requires; and
pay the fee required under Title 4, Subtitle 2 of the Health - General Article for a copy of a record.

paragraph.text: A biological parent may:

subparagraph.text: file with the Director a disclosure veto, to bar disclosure of information about that parent in a record accessible under this section;
cancel a disclosure veto at any time; and
refile a disclosure veto at any time.

paragraph.text: An adoptee at least 21 years old may:

subparagraph.text: file with the Director a disclosure veto, to bar disclosure of information about the adoptee in a record accessible under this section;
cancel a disclosure veto at any time; and
refile a disclosure veto at any time.

paragraph.text: Immediately after the Director receives a disclosure veto or cancellation under this subsection, the Director shall forward a copy to the Secretary.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations to carry out this section.

Subject to paragraphs (3) and (4) of this subsection, the Secretary shall give to each applicant who meets the requirements of this section a copy of each record that the applicant requested and that the Secretary has on file.
Whenever a biological parent applies for a record, the Secretary shall redact from the copy all information as to:

subparagraph.text: the other biological parent, if that parent has filed a disclosure veto in accordance with this section; and
the adoptee and each adoptive parent, if the adoptee has filed a disclosure veto in accordance with this section.

paragraph.text: Whenever an adoptee applies for a record, the Secretary shall redact from the copy all information as to a biological parent, if that parent has filed a disclosure veto in accordance with this section.
The Secretary shall give each applicant under this section notice of the adoption search, contact, and reunion services available under Subtitle 4B of this title.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, access to a dental or medical record of an adopted minor may not be denied to a parent of the minor because the parent is an adoptive parent.
Access to a dental or medical record under this section may not include access to any part of the record that has identifying information as to a former parent of the minor.
Except as otherwise provided by law, a person may not charge or receive, from or for a parent or prospective adoptive parent, any compensation for a service in connection with:

paragraph.text: placement of an individual to live with a preadoptive parent, as defined in § 3-823(i)(1) of the Courts Article; or
an agreement for custody in contemplation of adoption.
In this subsection, “Administration” means the Social Services Administration of the Department.
This section does not:

subparagraph.text: prohibit payment, by an interested person, of a customary and reasonable charge or fee for hospital, legal, or medical services; or

prevent the Administration, or a person that the Administration licenses or supervises, from receiving and accepting reasonable reimbursement for costs of an adoptive service in connection with adoption, if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the reimbursement is in accordance with standards set by regulation of the Administration; and
the ability to provide this reimbursement does not affect:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the acceptability of any individual for adoptive services; or
the choice of the most suitable prospective adoptive parent.

subsection.text: Each State’s Attorney shall enforce this section.

A person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 or imprisonment not exceeding 3 months or both, for each offense.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Child” means an individual who is the subject of a guardianship or adoption petition under this subtitle.
“Guardianship” means an award, under this subtitle, of any power of a guardian.
“Identifying information” means information that reveals the identity or location of an individual.

paragraph.text: “Parent” means an individual who, at the time a petition for guardianship or adoption is filed under this subtitle or at any time before a court terminates the individual’s parental rights:

subparagraph.text: meets a criterion in § 5-3A-06(a) of this subtitle; or
is the mother.

paragraph.text: “Parent” does not include an individual whom a court has adjudicated not to be a father or mother.

subsection.text: This subtitle applies only to:

paragraph.text: guardianship by a child placement agency of a child other than a child in need of assistance; and
adoption of the child.

subsection.text: Except as expressly provided in this subtitle, this subtitle does not apply to any case pending on or before December 31, 2005.
The General Assembly finds that the policies and procedures of this subtitle are desirable and socially necessary.
The purposes of this subtitle are to:

paragraph.text: timely provide permanent and safe homes for children consistent with their best interests;
protect children from unnecessary separation from their parents;
ensure adoption only by individuals fit for the responsibility;
protect parents from making hurried or ill-considered agreements to terminate parental rights;
protect prospective adoptive parents by providing them information about prospective adoptees and their backgrounds; and
protect adoptive parents from a future disturbance of their relationship with adoptees by former parents.

section.text: This subtitle is related to and should be read in relation to Subtitle 5 of this title.

subsection.text: In this section, “order” includes any action that, under the laws of another jurisdiction, has the force and effect of a comparable judicial order under this subtitle.
In accordance with the United States Constitution, this State shall accord full faith and credit to:

paragraph.text: an order of another state as to adoption or guardianship in compliance with the other state’s laws; and
termination of parental rights in compliance with the other state’s laws.

subsection.text: As to a jurisdiction other than a state:

paragraph.text: an order for adoption or guardianship entered in compliance with the jurisdiction’s laws shall have the same legal effect as an order for adoption or guardianship entered in this State; and
termination of parental rights in compliance with the jurisdiction’s laws shall have the same legal effect as termination of parental rights in this State.

subsection.text: This section may not be construed to require an individual to petition a court in this State for adoption of an adoptee if:

paragraph.text: the individual adopted the adoptee in compliance with the laws of a jurisdiction other than a state; and
the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services verifies the validity of that adoption by granting, under the federal Immigration and Nationality Act, an IR-3 visa for the adoptee.

subsection.text: Unless a court excludes a man as the father of a child, a man is the father if:

paragraph.text: the man was married to the child’s mother at the time of the child’s conception;
the man was married to the child’s mother at the time of the child’s birth;
the man is named as the father on the child’s birth certificate and has not signed a denial of paternity;
the child’s mother has named the man as the child’s father and the man has not signed a denial of paternity;
the man has been adjudicated to be the child’s father;
the man has acknowledged himself, orally or in writing, to be the child’s father and the mother agrees; or
on the basis of genetic testing, the man is indicated to be the child’s biological father.
A petitioner under this subtitle shall give a court notice that a man who is not named in the petition and has not been excluded as a father claims paternity.
After a request of a party or claimant and before ruling on a petition for guardianship or adoption under this subtitle, a court shall hold a hearing on the issue of paternity.
In a case under this subtitle, a court shall appoint an attorney to represent a parent who:

subparagraph.text: has a disability that makes the parent incapable of effectively participating in the case; or
when the parent must decide whether to consent under this subtitle, is still a minor.

paragraph.text: To determine whether a disability makes a parent incapable of effectively participating in a case, a court, on its own motion or on motion of a party, may order examination of the parent.
In an adoption proceeding under this subtitle, a court shall appoint an attorney to represent a prospective adoptee who:

subparagraph.text: is at least 10 years old; and

sub-subparagraph.text: is a minor; or
has a disability that makes the prospective adoptee incapable of effectively participating in the proceeding.

paragraph.text: To determine whether a disability makes a child incapable of effectively participating in a case, a court, on its own motion or on motion of a party, may order examination of the child.

subsection.text: An attorney or firm:

paragraph.text: may represent more than one party in a case under this subtitle only if the Maryland Rules of Professional Conduct allow; and
may not represent a prospective adoptive parent and parent in the same case.

subsection.text: Counsel appointed under this section may be compensated for reasonable fees, as approved by the court.

paragraph.text: A prospective adoptive parent and parent of a prospective adoptee under this subtitle may enter into a written agreement to allow contact, after the adoption, between:

subparagraph.text: the parent or other relative of the adoptee; and
the adoptee or adoptive parent.

paragraph.text: An adoptive parent and former parent of an adoptee under this subtitle may enter into a written agreement to allow contact between:

subparagraph.text: a relative or former parent of the adoptee; and
the adoptee or adoptive parent.

subsection.text: An agreement made under this section applies to contact with an adoptee only while the adoptee is a minor.
An individual who prepares an agreement described in subsection (a)(1) of this section:

paragraph.text: shall provide a copy to each party in a case pending as to the prospective adoptee under this subtitle; and
if the agreement so provides, shall redact identifying information from all copies.

subsection.text: Failure to comply with a condition of an agreement made under this section is not a ground for revoking consent to, or setting aside an order for, adoption or guardianship.
If a dispute as to an agreement made under this section arises, a court may order the parties to engage in mediation to try to resolve the dispute.

paragraph.text: A court shall enforce a written agreement made in accordance with this section unless enforcement is not in the adoptee’s best interests.

If a party moves to modify a written agreement made in accordance with this section and satisfies the court that modification is justified because an exceptional circumstance has arisen and the court finds modification to be in an adoptee’s best interests, the court may modify the agreement.

section.text: A court may assign among the parties to a case under this subtitle, as the court considers appropriate, counsel fees and the cost of testing under § 5-3A-06 of this subtitle.
A party to a case under this subtitle may appeal to the Court of Special Appeals from an interlocutory or final order.

subsection.text: Only a child placement agency may petition for guardianship under this subtitle.
A court may grant guardianship under this subtitle only for a minor.
A petitioner shall attach to a petition:

paragraph.text: all written consents for the guardianship that the petitioner has; and
if applicable:

subparagraph.text: proof of guardianship or relinquishment of parental rights granted by an administrative, executive, or judicial body of a state or other jurisdiction; and
certification that the guardianship or relinquishment was granted in compliance with the jurisdiction’s laws.

subsection.text: Within 5 days after a petition for guardianship of a child is filed with a court, the clerk shall send a copy of the petition and notice of filing to:

paragraph.text: each of the child’s living parents who has not waived the right to notice; and
each living parent’s attorney of record.

subsection.text: Notice under this section shall be by first-class mail.
Notice to a parent under this section shall be sent to a parent’s last address known to the court.
On issuance of a show cause order as to guardianship of a child, a petitioner shall serve the order on each of the child’s living parents who has not consented to the guardianship.
Service under this section shall be by:

paragraph.text: personal service; or
certified mail, restricted delivery, return receipt requested.

subsection.text: Service on a parent under this section shall be attempted at the parent’s last address known to the petitioner.

paragraph.text: If a court is satisfied, by affidavit or testimony, that, after reasonable efforts in good faith, a petitioner could not identify a parent or could not effect service on a parent, the court shall order service through notice by publication as to that parent.
Notice under this subsection shall consist of substantially the following statement:
To: (Father’s name) To: (Mother’s name) To: Unknown parent

“You are hereby notified that a guardianship case has been filed in the circuit court for (county name), case no. (number). All persons who believe themselves to be parents of a (male or female) child born on (date of birth) in (city, state) to (mother’s and father’s names and dates of birth) shall file a written response. A copy of the show cause order may be obtained from the clerk’s office at (address) and (telephone number). If you do not file a written objection by (deadline), you will have agreed to the permanent loss of your parental rights to this child.”
Service under this subsection shall be by:

subparagraph.text: publication at least once in one or more newspapers in general circulation in the county where the parent last resided or, if unknown, where the petition is filed; and
posting for at least 30 days on a website of the Department.

paragraph.text: The Department may charge a petitioner a reasonable fee to cover the cost of posting.

section.text: Before ruling on a guardianship petition, a court may order any investigation that the court considers necessary.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, a court shall rule on a guardianship petition under this subtitle within 180 days after the petition is filed.
A court may not enter a final order for guardianship under this subtitle until the later of expiration of the time for:

paragraph.text: revocation of consent; or
the filing of a response to an order to show cause.

subsection.text: A court may grant a guardianship of a child only if:

paragraph.text: each of the child’s living parents consents:

subparagraph.text: in writing; or
by failure to timely file notice of objection after being served with a show cause order in accordance with this subtitle;

paragraph.text: an administrative, executive, or judicial body of a state or other jurisdiction has granted a governmental unit or person other than a parent the power to consent to adoption, and the governmental unit or person consents; or
parental rights have been terminated in compliance with the laws of a state or other jurisdiction, as described in § 5-3A-05 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A governmental unit or person:

paragraph.text: may condition consent or acquiescence on adoption into a specific family that a child placement agency has approved for the placement; but
may not condition consent or acquiescence on any factor other than placement into a specific family.
Consent of a parent may include a waiver of the right to notice of:

subparagraph.text: the filing of a petition under this subtitle; and
further proceedings under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Consent to guardianship is not valid unless the consent:

subparagraph.text: is given after the child for whom guardianship is sought is born;
is given in a language that the party understands;
if given in a language other than English:

sub-subparagraph.text: is given before a judge on the record; or
is accompanied by the affidavit of a translator stating that the translation of the document of consent is accurate;

subparagraph.text: contains an express notice of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the right to revoke consent, at any time within 30 days after the person signs the consent, unless the revocation is barred under subsection (b)(2) of this section;
the search rights of adoptees and parents under § 5-3A-42 of this subtitle and the search rights of adoptees, parents, and siblings under Subtitle 4B of this title; and
the right to file a disclosure veto under § 5-3A-42 of this subtitle; and

subparagraph.text: is accompanied by an affidavit of counsel appointed under § 5-3A-07(a) of this subtitle stating that a parent who is a minor or has a disability consents knowingly and voluntarily.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a person may revoke consent to guardianship at any time within 30 days after the person signs the consent.
A parent may not revoke consent for guardianship of a child if:

subparagraph.text: in the preceding year, the parent has revoked consent for or filed a notice of objection to guardianship of the child; and
the child is at least 30 days old and consent is given before a judge on the record.

subsection.text: If a petitioner becomes aware, before a court rules on a petition, that a condition of consent under § 5-3A-18(b) of this subtitle cannot be fulfilled, the petitioner promptly shall:

paragraph.text: file notice with the court;
give notice to all of the other parties;
if consent was received from a governmental unit or person who is not a party, give notice to that unit or person; and

subparagraph.text: if the unit or person enters into a new consent, file the consent with the court; or
if the unit or person fails to enter into a new consent, dismiss the petition.

subsection.text: If all consents for guardianship of a child have been given in accordance with this subtitle, a court may enter an order for guardianship.

paragraph.text: Within 5 days after entry of an order under this section, a court shall notify each party to the case who has not waived the right to notice.
Notice under this subsection shall be by first-class mail.
Notice under this subsection shall be sent to a party’s last address known to the court.

section.text: In an order entered under this subtitle, a court shall document:

paragraph.text: the response by each party to the guardianship petition; and
the waiver, if any, of a parent to notice of further proceedings.

subsection.text: An order for guardianship of an individual:

paragraph.text: except as provided in § 5-3A-23 of this subtitle, § 4-414 of the Estates and Trusts Article, and § 2-123 of the Real Property Article, terminates a parent’s duties, obligations, and rights toward the individual;
eliminates the need for notice to a parent as to the filing of an adoption petition;
eliminates the need for further consent of a parent to adoption of the individual; and
grants guardianship of the individual to a child placement agency.
Unless a court gives legal custody to another person, a child’s guardian under this subtitle has legal custody.
Unless a court orders otherwise and subject to review by the court, a child’s guardian may make all decisions affecting the child’s education, health, and welfare, including consenting to:

subparagraph.text: adoption of the child;
application by the child for a driver’s license;
enlistment by the child in the armed forces;
marriage of the child; and
medical, psychiatric, or surgical treatment.

paragraph.text: A child placement agency shall file a written report with a court with jurisdiction over a child whenever:

subparagraph.text: the child placement agency fails to place the child for adoption with a preadoptive parent, as defined in § 3-823(i)(1) of the Courts Article:

sub-subparagraph.text: within 270 days after being awarded guardianship; or
within 180 days after permanently removing the child from another placement; or

subparagraph.text: a court does not enter a final order of adoption within 2 years after the placement.

paragraph.text: A report under this subsection shall state each reason for the delay in placement or adoption.
Whenever a child placement agency files a report under this section, the child placement agency shall mail notice of the child’s status:

subparagraph.text: to each of the child’s living parents who has not waived the right to notice and, if represented, counsel; and
if a court appointed counsel for the child under this subtitle, to the child’s last attorney of record.

paragraph.text: A waiver of rights under this subsection is not valid unless the waiver appears expressly in:

subparagraph.text: the parent’s consent to guardianship; and
the guardianship order.

paragraph.text: Whenever a court receives a report under this section, the court shall hold a hearing to:

subparagraph.text: review the progress that the child placement agency has made toward adoption of the child; and
take all actions that the court considers to be in the child’s best interests.

paragraph.text: Each year after a hearing under paragraph (1) of this subsection until the court’s jurisdiction terminates, the court shall hold another review hearing.

section.text: If a petitioner becomes aware, after a court rules on a petition, that a condition of consent under § 5-3A-18(b) of this subtitle cannot be fulfilled, the petitioner promptly shall:

paragraph.text: file notice with the court;
give notice to all of the other parties;
if consent was received from a governmental unit or person who is not a party, give notice to that unit or person; and

subparagraph.text: if the unit or person enters into a new consent, file the consent with the court;
if the unit or person fails to enter into a new consent, ask the court to set aside the guardianship order; or

if the unit or person cannot be located after exhaustion of the service requirements under § 5-3A-15 of this subtitle, ask the court to determine whether it is in the child’s best interests to continue the guardianship despite the inability to fulfill the condition.

subsection.text: Unless terminated sooner, a court retains jurisdiction over a child until the child attains 18 years of age.
An order for adoption of a child terminates the child’s guardianship case.
Any adult may petition a court for an adoption under this subtitle.
A petitioner may petition for adoption of a child 180 days or more after a child placement agency places the child with the petitioner.

paragraph.text: If a petitioner under this section is married, the petitioner’s spouse shall join in the petition unless the spouse:

subparagraph.text: is separated from the petitioner under a circumstance that gives the petitioner a ground for annulment or divorce; or
is not competent to join in the petition.

paragraph.text: If the marital status of a petitioner changes before entry of a final order, the petitioner shall amend the petition accordingly.

section.text: A petitioner for adoption under this subtitle shall give notice of the filing of an adoption petition to each person whose consent is required.
Before a court enters an order for adoption of a child under this subtitle, a child placement agency shall file a written report on:

paragraph.text: the suitability of the petitioner to adopt the child; and
the relationship between the petitioner and child.

section.text: A court shall hold a hearing before entering an order for adoption under this subtitle.
A court may not enter an order for adoption under this subtitle until 30 days after entry of a guardianship order under this subtitle.

subsection.text: In ruling on a petition for a child’s adoption under this Part III of this subtitle, a court shall consider:

paragraph.text: all factors necessary to determine the child’s best interests; and
the report required under § 5-3A-31 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In ruling on an adoption petition under this Part III of this subtitle, a court may not deny the petition solely because the petitioner is single or unmarried.
A court may enter an order for a child’s adoption under this subtitle only if:

paragraph.text: the child placement agency consents; and
for a child who is at least 10 years old, the child consents.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection, “disability” means:

sub-subparagraph.text: a physical disability, infirmity, malformation, or disfigurement that is caused by bodily injury, birth defect, or illness, including epilepsy;
a mental impairment or deficiency;
a record of having a physical or mental impairment as defined under this paragraph; or
being regarded as having a physical or mental impairment as defined under this paragraph.

subparagraph.text: “Disability” includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: any degree of paralysis or amputation;
blindness or visual impairment;
deafness or hearing impairment;
muteness or speech impediment;
physical reliance on a service animal or a wheelchair or other remedial appliance or device; and

intellectual disability, as defined in § 7–101 of the Health – General Article, and any other mental impairment or deficiency that may have necessitated remedial or special education and related services.

paragraph.text: A child placement agency may not withhold consent for the sole reason that:

subparagraph.text: the race, religion, color, or national origin of a prospective adoptive parent differs from that of the child or parent; or
a prospective adoptive parent has a disability.

subsection.text: Consent of a party to an adoption under this Part III of this subtitle is not valid unless:

paragraph.text: the consent is given in a language that the party understands;
if given in a language other than English, the consent:

subparagraph.text: is given before a judge on the record; or
is accompanied by the affidavit of a translator stating that the translation of the document of consent is accurate;

paragraph.text: the consent names the child;
the consent contains enough information to identify the prospective adoptive parent; and
the party has received written notice or on-the-record notice of:

subparagraph.text: the revocation provisions in this section;
