the search rights of adoptees and parents under § 5-3A-42 of this subtitle and the search rights of adoptees, parents, and siblings under Subtitle 4B of this title; and
the right to file a disclosure veto under § 5-3A-42 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: A child placement agency may revoke consent at any time within the later of:

subparagraph.text: 14 days after the child placement agency signs the consent; or
14 days after the adoption petition is filed.

paragraph.text: A child who is at least 10 years old may revoke consent at any time before a court enters an order of adoption under this subtitle.
This subsection does not limit the right of an individual to provide for distribution of property by will.
Except as provided in § 2-123 of the Real Property Article, after a court enters an order for adoption under this subtitle:

subparagraph.text: the adoptee:

sub-subparagraph.text: is the child of the adoptive parent for all intents and purposes; and
is entitled to all of the rights and privileges of and is subject to all of the obligations of offspring born to the adoptive parent;

subparagraph.text: each of the adoptee’s living parents is:

sub-subparagraph.text: relieved of all parental duties and obligations to the adoptee; and
divested of all parental rights as to the adoptee; and

subparagraph.text: the Estates and Trusts Article shall govern all of the rights of inheritance between the adoptee and parental relatives.

subsection.text: An order for adoption under this subtitle terminates all pending guardianship cases as to the adoptee.
Adoption of an adult has the same legal effect as adoption of a minor.

paragraph.text: When a court enters an order for a child’s adoption under this subtitle, the court shall send notice to:

subparagraph.text: each court that has a pending guardianship case as to the adoptee;
each of the child’s living, former parents who has not waived the right to notice; and
the former guardian of the child.

paragraph.text: Service on a parent under this subsection shall be at the parent’s last address known to the court.

section.text: If a petition to invalidate an order for adoption under this subtitle on the basis of a jurisdictional or procedural defect is filed more than 1 year after entry of the order, a court shall dismiss the petition.

subsection.text: A child placement agency shall make reasonable efforts to compile and make available to a prospective adoptive parent:

paragraph.text: all of the prospective adoptee’s medical and mental health records that the agency has; or
a comprehensive medical and mental health history of the prospective adoptee.

subsection.text: On request of a prospective adoptive parent, a child placement agency shall make reasonable efforts to compile a pertinent medical and mental health history of each of the prospective adoptee’s parents, if available to the agency, and to make the history available to the prospective adoptive parent.

paragraph.text: If, after adoption, a child placement agency receives medical or mental health information about the adoptee or adoptee’s former parent, the agency shall make reasonable efforts to make the information available to the adoptive parent.

If, after adoption, the adoptive parent requests additional information, the child placement agency shall make reasonable efforts to notify the former parent, at the former parent’s last known address available to the agency, of the request and the reason for the request.

subsection.text: A medical or mental health history compiled under this section may not contain identifying information as to a parent.

subparagraph.text: On request of an adoptee or adoptive or former parent of an adoptee and without a showing of a need, a child placement agency shall provide information, other than identifying information, in its adoption record on the adoptee.

If a child placement agency denies a request under this paragraph, then on petition of an adoptee or adoptive or former parent and without a showing of need, a court shall order access for the petitioner to inspect, in accordance with subsection (b) of this section, the agency’s record on the adoptee.

paragraph.text: On petition of an adoptee or adoptive or former parent of an adoptee and without a showing of need, a court shall order access for the petitioner to inspect, in accordance with subsection (b) of this section, the court’s record on the adoptee.

subsection.text: A court may not order opened for inspection under this section any part of a record that contains identifying information.

If, after a hearing on petition of an adoptee or former parent, a court is satisfied that the adoptee or blood relative of the adoptee or former parent urgently needs medical information not in agency and court records, the court may appoint an intermediary to try to contact the adoptee or a former parent of the adoptee for the information.
An intermediary appointed under this section:

paragraph.text: only may advise an adoptee or former parent of the need for medical information; and
may not:

subparagraph.text: reveal any identifying information about an adoptee or former parent; or
try, in any manner, to encourage or discourage contact between an adoptee and former parent.

subsection.text: An intermediary appointed under this section shall file with the appointing court a confidential written report on the intermediary’s efforts to contact an adoptee or former parent.
When a court receives a report from an intermediary, the court may disclose to the adoptee or former parent, without revealing identifying information about the adoptee or any former parent:

paragraph.text: whether the intermediary advised the adoptee or former parent about the need for medical information; and
medical information that the adoptee or former parent provided.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a court may order an adoptee or former parent to pay a reasonable fee for the services of an intermediary under this section.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Director” means the State Director of Social Services.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene.

subsection.text: This section applies only to an adoption in which a court enters an order for adoption on or after January 1, 2000.
This section does not bar:

paragraph.text: an adoptee or biological parent from applying for search, contact, and reunion services under Subtitle 4B of this title; or
the Director or a confidential intermediary from obtaining a copy of a record under § 5-4B-04(c) or § 5-4B-06(b) or (c) of this title.
An adoptee who is at least 21 years old may apply to the Secretary for a copy of:

subparagraph.text: the adoptee’s original certificate of birth;
all records that relate to the adoptee’s new certificate of birth, if any; and
the report of the adoptee’s order of adoption filed by the clerk of court under § 4-211 of the Health - General Article.

paragraph.text: If an adoptee is at least 21 years old, a biological parent of the adoptee may apply to the Secretary for a copy of:

subparagraph.text: the adoptee’s original certificate of birth;
the new certificate of birth, if any, substituted, under § 4-211 of the Health - General Article, for the adoptee’s original certificate of birth;
all records that relate to the adoptee’s new certificate of birth; and
the report of the adoptee’s order of adoption filed by the clerk of court under § 4-211 of the Health - General Article.

paragraph.text: Each applicant under this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: provide all proof of identity and other relevant information that the Secretary requires; and
pay the fee required under Title 4, Subtitle 2 of the Health - General Article for a copy of a record.

paragraph.text: A biological parent may:

subparagraph.text: file with the Director a disclosure veto, to bar disclosure of information about that parent in a record accessible under this section;
cancel a disclosure veto at any time; and
refile a disclosure veto at any time.

paragraph.text: An adoptee at least 21 years old may:

subparagraph.text: file with the Director a disclosure veto, to bar disclosure of information about the adoptee in a record accessible under this section;
cancel a disclosure veto at any time; and
refile a disclosure veto at any time.

paragraph.text: Immediately after the Director receives a disclosure veto or cancellation under this subsection, the Director shall forward a copy to the Secretary.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations to carry out this section.

Subject to paragraphs (3) and (4) of this subsection, the Secretary shall give to each applicant who meets the requirements of this section a copy of each record that the applicant requested and that the Secretary has on file.
Whenever a biological parent applies for a record, the Secretary shall redact from the copy all information as to:

subparagraph.text: the other biological parent, if that parent has filed a disclosure veto in accordance with this section; and
the adoptee and each adoptive parent, if the adoptee has filed a disclosure veto in accordance with this section.

paragraph.text: Whenever an adoptee applies for a record, the Secretary shall redact from the copy all information as to the biological parent, if that parent has filed a disclosure veto in accordance with this section.
The Secretary shall give each applicant under this section notice of the adoption search, contact, and reunion services available under this title.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, access to a dental or medical record of an adopted minor may not be denied to a parent of the minor because the parent is an adoptive parent.
Access to a dental or medical record under this section may not include access to any part of the record that has identifying information as to a former parent of the minor.
Except as otherwise provided by law, a person may not charge or receive, from or for a parent or prospective adoptive parent, any compensation for a service in connection with:

paragraph.text: placement of an individual to live with a preadoptive family; or
an agreement for custody in contemplation of adoption.
In this subsection, “Administration” means the Social Services Administration of the Department.
This section does not:

subparagraph.text: prohibit payment, by an interested person, of a customary and reasonable charge or fee for hospital, legal, or medical services; or

prevent the Administration, or a person that the Administration licenses or supervises, from receiving and accepting reasonable reimbursement for costs of an adoptive service in connection with adoption, if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the reimbursement is in accordance with standards set by regulation of the Administration; and
the ability to provide this reimbursement does not affect:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the acceptability of any individual for adoptive services; or
the choice of the most suitable prospective adoptive parent.

subsection.text: Each State’s Attorney shall enforce this section.

A person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 or imprisonment not exceeding 3 months or both, for each offense.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Identifying information” means information that reveals the identity or location of an individual.

paragraph.text: “Parent” means an individual who, at any time before a court enters an order for adoption under this subtitle:

subparagraph.text: meets a criterion in § 5-3B-05(a) of this subtitle; or
is the mother.

paragraph.text: “Parent” does not include an individual whom a court has adjudicated not to be a father or mother.

subsection.text: “Prospective adoptee” means an individual who is the subject of a petition for adoption under this subtitle.
This subtitle applies only to an adoption that is arranged other than by a child placement agency.
Except as expressly provided in this subtitle, it does not affect an adoption:

paragraph.text: for which a court entered an order on or before December 31, 2005; or
pending on January 1, 2006.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that the policies and procedures of this subtitle are desirable and socially necessary.
The purposes of this subtitle are to:

paragraph.text: timely provide permanent and safe homes for children consistent with their best interests;
protect children from unnecessary separation from their parents;
ensure adoption only by individuals fit for the responsibility;
protect parents from making hurried or ill-considered agreements to terminate their parental rights;
protect prospective adoptive parents by giving them information about prospective adoptees and their backgrounds; and
protect adoptive parents from future disturbances of their relationships with adoptees by former parents.

subsection.text: In this section, “order” includes any action that, under the laws of another jurisdiction, has the force and effect of a comparable judicial order under this subtitle.
In accordance with the United States Constitution, this State shall accord full faith and credit to:

paragraph.text: an order of another state as to adoption or guardianship in compliance with the other state’s laws; and
termination of parental rights in compliance with the other state’s laws.

subsection.text: As to a jurisdiction other than a state:

paragraph.text: an order for adoption or guardianship entered in compliance with the jurisdiction’s laws shall have the same legal effect as an order for adoption or guardianship entered in this State; and
termination of parental rights in compliance with the jurisdiction’s laws shall have the same legal effect as termination of parental rights in this State.

subsection.text: This section may not be construed to require an individual to petition a court in this State for adoption of an adoptee if:

paragraph.text: the individual adopted the adoptee in compliance with the laws of a jurisdiction other than a state; and
the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services verifies the validity of that adoption by granting, under the federal Immigration and Nationality Act, an IR-3 visa for the adoptee.

subsection.text: Unless a court excludes a man as the father of a child, a man is the father if:

paragraph.text: the man was married to the child’s mother at the time of the child’s conception;
the man was married to the child’s mother at the time of the child’s birth;
the man is named as the father on the child’s birth certificate and has not signed a denial of paternity;
the child’s mother has named the man as the child’s father and the man has not signed a denial of paternity;
the man has been adjudicated to be the child’s father;
the man has acknowledged himself, orally or in writing, to be the child’s father and the mother agrees; or
on the basis of genetic testing, the man is indicated to be the child’s biological father.
A petitioner under this subtitle shall give a court notice that a man who is not named in the petition and has not been excluded as a father claims paternity.
After a request of a party or claimant and before ruling on a petition for adoption under this subtitle, a court shall hold a hearing on the issue of paternity.
In a case under this subtitle, a court shall appoint an attorney to represent a parent who:

subparagraph.text: has a disability that makes the parent incapable of effectively participating in the case; or
when the parent must decide whether to consent to adoption, is still a minor.

paragraph.text: To determine whether a disability makes a parent incapable of effectively participating in a case, a court, on its own motion or on motion of a party, may order examination of the parent.
In a case under this subtitle, a court shall appoint an attorney to represent a prospective adoptee who:

subparagraph.text: has a disability that makes the prospective adoptee incapable of effectively participating in the case; and
when the prospective adoptee must decide whether to consent to adoption, is at least 10 years old.

paragraph.text: To determine whether a disability makes a prospective adoptee incapable of effectively participating in a case, a court, on its own motion or on motion of a party, may order examination of the prospective adoptee.

subsection.text: An attorney or firm:

paragraph.text: may represent more than one party in a case under this subtitle only if the Maryland Lawyers’ Rules of Professional Conduct allow; and
may not represent a prospective adoptive parent and parent in the same adoption case.

subsection.text: Counsel appointed under this section may be compensated for reasonable fees, as approved by the court.

paragraph.text: A prospective adoptive parent and parent of a prospective adoptee may enter into a written agreement to allow contact, after the adoption, between:

subparagraph.text: the parent or other relative of the adoptee; and
the adoptee and adoptive parent.

paragraph.text: An adoptive parent and former parent of an adoptee under this subtitle may enter into a written agreement to allow contact between:

subparagraph.text: a relative or former parent of the adoptee; and
the adoptee or adoptive parent.

subsection.text: An agreement made under this section applies to contact with an adoptee only while the adoptee is a minor.
An individual who prepares an agreement described in subsection (a)(1) of this section:

paragraph.text: shall provide a copy to each party in a case pending as to the prospective adoptee under this subtitle; and
if the agreement so provides, shall redact identifying information from the copies.

subsection.text: Failure to comply with a condition of an agreement made under this section is not a ground for revoking consent to, or setting aside an order for, adoption.
If a dispute as to an agreement made under this section arises, a court may order the parties to engage in mediation to try to resolve the dispute.

paragraph.text: A court shall enforce a written agreement made in accordance with this section unless enforcement is not in the adoptee’s best interests.

If a party moves to modify a written agreement made in accordance with this section and satisfies the court that modification is justified because an exceptional circumstance has arisen and the court finds modification to be in an adoptee’s best interests, the court may modify the agreement.

subsection.text: A court may order an adoptive parent to pay, wholly or partly, reasonable fees for a former parent’s:

paragraph.text: independent counsel; or
adoption counseling or guidance for a reasonable time.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (a) of this section, a court may assign among the parties to a case under this subtitle counsel fees, counseling or guidance fees, and costs of testing under § 5-3B-05 of this subtitle, as the court considers appropriate.

section.text: A party to a case under this subtitle may appeal to the Court of Special Appeals from an interlocutory or final order.

Except for a child being placed for adoption with a relative of the child, by blood or marriage within 4 degrees of affinity or consanguinity under the civil law rule, a parent or grandparent may place a child for adoption only if:

paragraph.text: a petition for adoption is filed in court; and
the court, by order, sanctions the placement pending final action on the petition.

subsection.text: Any adult or minor may be adopted under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Any adult may petition a court for adoption.
If a petitioner is married, the petitioner’s spouse shall join in the petition unless the spouse:

subparagraph.text: is separated from the petitioner under a circumstance that gives the petitioner a ground for annulment or divorce;
is not competent to join in the petition; or

sub-subparagraph.text: is a parent of the prospective adoptee; and
has consented to the adoption in accordance with this subtitle.

subsection.text: Before a petition is filed under this subtitle, a petitioner shall move for, and a court shall order that, a case pending under Subtitle 3 of this title be closed.
If the marital status of a petitioner changes before entry of an order under this subtitle, the petitioner shall amend the petition accordingly.

section.text: A court shall give notice of the filing of an adoption petition to each individual whose consent has been filed under this subtitle and who has not waived the right to notice.

subsection.text: Subsection (b) of this section does not apply to an adoption by a spouse of the prospective adoptee’s parent or a relative of the prospective adoptee.
A court shall issue a show–cause order that includes advice as to the parent’s rights to:

paragraph.text: have independent counsel; and
receive adoption counseling and guidance.

subsection.text: On issuance of a show–cause order as to a prospective adoptee, a petitioner shall serve the order:

paragraph.text: on each of the prospective adoptee’s living parents who has not consented to the adoption; and
if the prospective adoptee is at least 10 years old and has not consented to the adoption, on the prospective adoptee.

subsection.text: Service under this section shall be by:

paragraph.text: personal service; or
certified mail, restricted delivery, return receipt requested.

subsection.text: Service under this section shall be attempted at the parent’s last address known to the petitioner.

paragraph.text: If a court is satisfied, by affidavit or testimony, that, after reasonable efforts in good faith, a petitioner could not identify a parent or could not effect service on a parent, the court shall order service through notice by publication as to that parent.
Notice under this subsection shall consist of substantially the following statement:

To: (Father’s name) To: (Mother’s name) To: Unknown parent “You are hereby notified that an adoption case has been filed in the circuit court for (county name), case no. (number). All persons who believe themselves to be parents of a (male or female) child born on (date of birth) in (city, state) to (mother’s and father’s names and dates of birth) shall file a written response. A copy of the show–cause order may be obtained from the clerk’s office at (address) and (telephone number). If you do not file a written objection by (deadline), you will have agreed to the permanent loss of your parental rights to this child.”
Service under this subsection shall be by:

subparagraph.text: publication at least once in one or more newspapers in general circulation in the county where the petition is filed or, if different, where the parent’s last address known to the petitioner is located; and
posting for at least 30 days on a website of the Department.

paragraph.text: The Department may charge a petitioner a reasonable fee to cover the cost of posting.

subsection.text: Before ruling on a consensual adoption petition under § 5-3B-20(1) of this subtitle, a court may order any investigation that the court considers necessary.

Before ruling on a nonconsensual adoption petition under §§ 5-3B-20(2) and 5-3B-22 of this subtitle, a court shall order an appropriate agency to investigate and submit a report that includes summaries of:

paragraph.text: the prospective adoptee’s emotional ties with and feelings toward the prospective adoptee’s parents, the prospective adoptee’s siblings, and others who may affect the prospective adoptee’s best interests significantly; and
the prospective adoptee’s adjustment to:

subparagraph.text: community;
home; and
school.

section.text: A court shall hold a hearing before entering an order for adoption under this subtitle.
A court may not enter an order for adoption under this subtitle until expiration of the revocation period.

subsection.text: In ruling on a petition for a prospective adoptee’s adoption under this subtitle, a court shall consider:

paragraph.text: all factors necessary to determine the prospective adoptee’s best interests; and
any report prepared for the court.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection, “disability” means:

sub-subparagraph.text: a physical disability, infirmity, malformation, or disfigurement that is caused by bodily injury, birth defect, or illness, including epilepsy;
a mental impairment or deficiency;
a record of having a physical or mental impairment as defined under this paragraph; or
being regarded as having a physical or mental impairment as defined under this paragraph.

subparagraph.text: “Disability” includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: any degree of paralysis or amputation;
blindness or visual impairment;
deafness or hearing impairment;
muteness or speech impediment;
physical reliance on a service animal or a wheelchair or other remedial appliance or device; and

intellectual disability, as defined in § 7–101 of the Health – General Article, and any other mental impairment or deficiency that may have necessitated remedial or special education and related services.

paragraph.text: In ruling on an adoption petition under this subtitle, a court may not deny the petition solely because the petitioner:

subparagraph.text: is single or unmarried; or
has a disability.

section.text: A court may enter an order for adoption only if:

sub-subparagraph.text: each of the prospective adoptee’s living parents consents:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: in writing; or
by failure to timely file notice of objection after being served with a show–cause order in accordance with this subtitle;

sub-subparagraph.text: an administrative, executive, or judicial body of a state or other jurisdiction has granted a governmental unit or person other than a parent the power to consent to adoption, and the unit or person consents; or
parental rights have been terminated in compliance with the laws of a state or other jurisdiction, as described in § 5–3B–04 of this subtitle; and

subparagraph.text: if the prospective adoptee is at least 10 years old, the prospective adoptee consents; or

paragraph.text: in accordance with § 5–3B–22 of this subtitle, the court orders adoption without consent otherwise required under this section.
Consent of a parent may include a waiver of rights to notice of:

subparagraph.text: the filing of a petition under this subtitle; and
further proceedings under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Consent to adoption under this subtitle is not valid unless the consent:

subparagraph.text: is given after the prospective adoptee is born;
is given in a language that the party understands;
if given in a language other than English:

sub-subparagraph.text: is given before a judge on the record; or
is accompanied by the affidavit of a translator stating that the translation of the document of consent is accurate;

subparagraph.text: contains an express notice of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the right to revoke consent, at any time within 30 days after the consent is signed;
the search rights of adoptees and parents under § 5-3B-29 of this subtitle and the search rights of adoptees, siblings, and parents under Subtitle 4B of this title; and
the right to file a disclosure veto under § 5-3B-29 of this subtitle;

subparagraph.text: except as to an adoption by a spouse of the prospective adoptee’s parent or a relative of the prospective adoptee, states that the parent has been advised of the parent’s rights to:

sub-subparagraph.text: have independent counsel; and
receive adoption counseling and guidance;

subparagraph.text: states whether the parent chose to have or not have counsel or counseling; and
is accompanied by an affidavit of counsel appointed under § 5-3B-06 of this subtitle stating that a parent who is a minor or has a disability gives consent knowingly and voluntarily.
Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a parent may revoke consent at any time within 30 days after the parent signs the consent.
A parent may not revoke consent for adoption of a prospective adoptee if:

sub-subparagraph.text: in the preceding year, the parent has revoked consent for or filed a notice of objection to adoption of the prospective adoptee; and
the child is at least 30 days old and consent is given before a judge on the record.

paragraph.text: A prospective adoptee may revoke consent at any time before a court enters an order of adoption under this subtitle.

subsection.text: This section applies only if a parent affirmatively withholds consent by filing a notice of objection.

paragraph.text: A court may allow adoption, without parental consent otherwise required under this subtitle, by a petitioner who has exercised physical care, control, or custody over the prospective adoptee for at least 180 days, if the court finds by clear and convincing evidence that:

subparagraph.text: the parent has not had custody of the prospective adoptee for at least 1 year;
the prospective adoptee has significant emotional ties to and feelings for the petitioner; and
the parent:

sub-subparagraph.text: has not maintained meaningful contact with the prospective adoptee while the petitioner had custody, notwithstanding an opportunity to do so;
has failed to contribute to the prospective adoptee’s physical care and support, notwithstanding the ability to do so;
has subjected the prospective adoptee to:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: chronic abuse;
chronic and life–threatening neglect;
sexual abuse; or
torture;

sub-subparagraph.text: has been convicted of abuse of any offspring;
has been convicted, in any state or any court of the United States, of:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: a crime of violence against:
a minor offspring of the parent;
the child; or
another parent of the child; or
aiding or abetting, conspiring, or soliciting to commit a crime described in item A of this item; or

sub-subparagraph.text: has, other than by consent, lost parental rights to a sibling of the prospective adoptee.

paragraph.text: If a court finds that an act or circumstance listed in paragraph (1)(iii)3 or 5 of this subsection exists, the court shall make a specific finding, based on facts in the record, whether return of the prospective adoptee to the custody of the parent poses an unacceptable risk to the prospective adoptee’s safety.
In determining whether it is in the best interests of a prospective adoptee to terminate a parent’s rights under this subsection, a court shall:

subparagraph.text: give primary consideration to the health and safety of the prospective adoptee; and
consider the report required under § 5–3B–16 of this subtitle.

section.text: A court may not grant a petition under § 5-3B-22 of this subtitle solely because a parent:

paragraph.text: does not have legal custody of a prospective adoptee by reason of a divorce or legal separation; or
has been deprived of custody of a prospective adoptee by an act of the other parent.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to an adoption by the spouse of the prospective adoptee’s parent or a relative of the prospective adoptee.

A court may not enter an order under this subtitle until the petitioner files with the court an accounting of all payments and disbursements of any item of value made by or for the petitioner in connection with the adoption.
This subsection does not limit the right of an individual to provide for distribution of property by will.
Except as provided in § 2-123 of the Real Property Article, after a court enters an order for adoption under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: the adoptee:

subparagraph.text: is the offspring of the adoptive parent for all intents and purposes; and
is entitled to all of the rights and privileges of and is subject to all of the obligations of offspring born to the adoptive parent;

paragraph.text: each of the adoptee’s living parents is:

subparagraph.text: relieved of all parental duties and obligations to the adoptee; and
divested of all parental rights as to the adoptee; and

paragraph.text: the Estates and Trusts Article shall govern all of the rights of inheritance between the adoptee and parental relatives.

subsection.text: Adoption of an adult has the same legal effect as adoption of a minor.

section.text: If a petition to invalidate an order under this subtitle on the basis of a jurisdictional or procedural defect is filed more than 1 year after entry of the order, a court shall dismiss the petition.

subsection.text: If, after a hearing on petition of an adoptee or former parent, a court is satisfied that the adoptee or blood relative of the adoptee or former parent urgently needs medical information not in court records, the court may appoint an intermediary to try to contact the adoptee or a former parent of the adoptee for the information.
An intermediary appointed under this section:

paragraph.text: only may advise an adoptee or former parent of the need for medical information; and
may not:

subparagraph.text: reveal any identifying information about an adoptee or former parent; or
try, in any manner, to encourage or discourage contact between an adoptee and former parent.

subsection.text: An intermediary appointed under this section shall file with the appointing court a confidential written report on the intermediary’s efforts to contact an adoptee or former parent.
When a court receives a report from an intermediary, the court may disclose to the adoptee or former parent, without revealing identifying information about the adoptee or any former parent:

paragraph.text: whether the intermediary advised the adoptee or a former parent about the need for medical information; and
medical information that the adoptee or a former parent provided.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a court may order an adoptee or former parent to pay a reasonable fee for the services of an intermediary under this section.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Director” means the State Director of Social Services.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene.

subsection.text: This section applies only to an adoption in which a court enters an order for adoption on or after January 1, 2000.
This section does not bar:

paragraph.text: an adoptee or biological parent from applying for search, contact, and reunion services under Subtitle 4B of this title; or
the Director or a confidential intermediary from obtaining a copy of a record under § 5-4B-04(c) or § 5-4B-06(b) or (c) of this title.
An adoptee who is at least 21 years old may apply to the Secretary for a copy of:

subparagraph.text: the adoptee’s original certificate of birth;
all records that relate to the adoptee’s new certificate of birth, if any; and
the report of the adoptee’s order of adoption filed by the clerk of court under § 4-211 of the Health - General Article.

paragraph.text: If an adoptee is at least 21 years old, a biological parent of the adoptee may apply to the Secretary for a copy of:

subparagraph.text: the adoptee’s original certificate of birth;
the new certificate of birth, if any, that was substituted, under § 4-211 of the Health - General Article, for the adoptee’s original certificate of birth;
all records that relate to the adoptee’s new certificate of birth; and
the report of the adoptee’s order of adoption filed by the clerk of court under § 4-211 of the Health - General Article.

paragraph.text: Each applicant under this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: provide all proof of identity and other relevant information that the Secretary requires; and
pay the fee required under Title 4, Subtitle 2 of the Health - General Article for a copy of a record.

paragraph.text: A biological parent may:

subparagraph.text: file with the Director a disclosure veto, to bar disclosure of information about that parent in a record accessible under this section;
cancel a disclosure veto at any time; and
refile a disclosure veto at any time.

paragraph.text: An adoptee 21 years old may:

subparagraph.text: file with the Director a disclosure veto, to bar disclosure of information about the adoptee in a record accessible under this section;
cancel a disclosure veto at any time; and
refile a disclosure veto at any time.

paragraph.text: Immediately after the Director receives a disclosure veto or cancellation under this subsection, the Director shall forward a copy to the Secretary.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations to carry out this section.

Subject to paragraphs (3) and (4) of this subsection, the Secretary shall give to each applicant who meets the requirements of this section a copy of each record that the applicant requested and that the Secretary has on file.
Whenever a biological parent applies for a record, the Secretary shall redact from the copy all information as to:

subparagraph.text: the other biological parent, if that parent has filed a disclosure veto in accordance with this section; and
the adoptee and each adoptive parent, if the adoptee has filed a disclosure veto in accordance with this section.

paragraph.text: Whenever an adoptee applies for a record, the Secretary shall redact from the copy all information as to the biological parent, if that parent has filed a disclosure veto in accordance with this section.
The Secretary shall give each applicant under this section notice of the adoption search, contact, and reunion services available under this title.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, access to a dental or medical record of an adopted minor may not be denied to a parent of the minor because the parent is an adoptive parent.
Access to a dental or medical record under this section may not include access to any part of the record that has identifying information as to a former parent of the minor.
Except as otherwise provided by law, a person may not charge or receive, from or for a parent or prospective adoptive parent, any compensation for a service in connection with:

paragraph.text: placement of an individual to live with a preadoptive family; or
an agreement for custody in contemplation of adoption.

subsection.text: This section does not prohibit payment, by an interested person, of a reasonable and customary charge or fee for adoption counseling, hospital, legal, or medical services.
Each State’s Attorney shall enforce this section.

A person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 or imprisonment not exceeding 3 months or both, for each offense.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administration” means the Social Services Administration of the Department.
“Eligible child” means a minor as to whom:

subparagraph.text: guardianship has been awarded to a child placement agency under Subtitle 3 or Subtitle 3A of this title; or
consensual adoption has been ordered under § 5–338 of this title; and

paragraph.text: a determination has been made by a local department under § 5–403 of this subtitle that a subsidy is necessary to ensure the child’s adoption because of the child’s special circumstances.

subsection.text: “Subsidy” means:

paragraph.text: a money payment;
medical care;
medical assistance; or
special services.

section.text: The purpose of this subtitle is to make possible, through a public subsidy, the most appropriate adoption of each eligible child.
The local department shall determine whether a subsidy is necessary to assure a child’s adoption because of the child’s special circumstances, including:

paragraph.text: physical or mental disability;
emotional disturbance;
recognized high risk of physical or mental disease;
age;
sibling relationship; and
racial or ethnic factors.

section.text: Each local department shall establish and administer an adoption subsidy program for eligible children.

subsection.text: Money payments and special services under the adoption subsidy program shall be funded by:

paragraph.text: appropriations to a local department for the maintenance of children in foster care; and
money that is made available to a local department from other sources.

subsection.text: Medical assistance and medical care under the adoption subsidy program shall be funded by:

paragraph.text: savings for the fiscal year by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene and the Department of Human Resources that are attributable to adoptions under this subtitle; and
appropriations to the Department of Human Resources for the adoption subsidy program.

subsection.text: The Administration may reimburse the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene for the cost of medical assistance and medical care directly or through a contract with the Department.
A subsidy may not be denied to an eligible child on the ground that the eligible child had a condition that was not known or discovered at the time of the adoption.

An individual who has been approved by a child placement agency as an appropriate adoptive parent and who seeks to adopt an eligible child is eligible to receive a subsidy on behalf of the eligible child regardless of the individual’s income or other eligibility factors.

A subsidy may not be denied to a child whose adoption has been dissolved or whose adoptive parents have died if the child received an adoption subsidy during the child’s prior adoption and the child continues to meet the criteria set forth in § 5-403 of this subtitle.
The subsidy may not be discontinued solely because the adoptive parent moves from this State with the eligible child.

A subsidy may continue to be provided for an eligible child to an adult who is qualified to assume responsibility and who assumes responsibility for the care and welfare of the child upon the death or incapacitation of the child’s adoptive parent.
To apply for a subsidy on behalf of an eligible child, an individual who is a prospective adoptive parent of the eligible child shall file an application for a subsidy with the local department.

paragraph.text: The director of the local department shall append to the application evidence of inability, after all reasonable efforts, to place the eligible child, without a subsidy, with an appropriate adoptive parent because of the special circumstances.

If the director of the local department determines that the eligible child has established emotional ties with a prospective adoptive parent who is the child’s foster parent, evidence of efforts to place the child with another prospective adoptive parent is not required.
Before a final decree of adoption is passed, the local department and a prospective adoptive parent of an eligible child shall make a written agreement regarding the subsidy.

In the case of an eligible child who has special circumstances that existed before the adoption but were not detected until after the adoption, the agreement shall be made promptly after the local department approves the application for a subsidy.

subsection.text: A subsidy may commence either at the time of the placement for adoption or at an appropriate time after the passage of the adoption decree.

paragraph.text: The nature, amount, and duration of the subsidy shall be determined by:

subparagraph.text: the needs of the eligible child because of the eligible child’s special circumstances; and
the availability of other resources to meet the eligible child’s needs.

paragraph.text: The subsidy may be for a limited or a long period of time.
The subsidy shall be in an amount that is not more than:

subparagraph.text: the allowable amount for a child under foster family care in this State, or if placement is in another state, the allowable amount for a child under foster family care in that state, whichever is higher;
in the case of a medically fragile child living in a treatment foster care home, $2,000 per month; or
if the subsidy is for a special service, a reasonable fee for that service.

paragraph.text: If, under a subsidy agreement, the subsidy does not terminate in the first year after the final decree of adoption is passed, the subsidy is subject to annual reapplication, reevaluation, and reapproval by the local department.
A subsidy agreement shall include a notice of the annual reapplication requirement.

subsection.text: If the Department makes the determinations under subsection (b) of this section, an adoptive parent involved in an independent or intercountry adoption of a child is entitled to reimbursement by the State for certain nonrecurring adoption expenses associated with the adoption.
An adoptive parent is eligible for reimbursement of nonrecurring adoption expenses, if the Department determines that:

paragraph.text: the child should not be returned to its biological parents;

the child cannot be placed with adoptive parents without providing assistance because of certain factors or conditions regarding the child, including ethnic background, age, the presence and number of siblings, or physical, mental, or emotional handicaps; and
except where it would be against the best interests of the child, previous adoption attempts have been made without assistance and were unsuccessful.

subsection.text: Application for nonrecurring adoption expenses shall be filed with the Department:

paragraph.text: prior to the order; and
on a form provided by the Department.
Upon approval of the application, there shall be a written agreement between the Department and the prospective adoptive parents regarding the reimbursement of nonrecurring adoption expenses.
Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the agreement shall be signed by the adoptive parents and an agent of the Department prior to the adoption order.
The agreement is not required to be signed by the adoptive parents and an agent of the Department prior to the adoption order if the order:

subparagraph.text: was entered between January 1, 1987 and July 1, 1990; or
was entered before January 1, 1987, but nonrecurring adoption expenses were paid after January 1, 1987.

paragraph.text: Adoptive parents filing for reimbursement of nonrecurring adoption expenses in cases described under paragraph (3) of this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: enter into a written agreement with the Department; and
file all claims no later than December 14, 1990.

subsection.text: Reimbursement for nonrecurring adoption expenses is limited to a maximum of $2,000 for reasonable and necessary actual costs that are not reimbursable from another source, including:

paragraph.text: adoption fees;
court costs and reasonable attorney’s fees;
health examinations;
transportation costs; and
food and lodging costs incurred during preplacement visits.

subsection.text: Except in cases described under subsection (d)(3) of this section, adoptive parents shall file all claims for nonrecurring adoption expenses within 2 years after the order.

section.text: An individual who is aggrieved by a final decision of the director of a local department that denies eligibility or reduces or terminates a subsidy in a contested case may:

paragraph.text: appeal that decision to the administrative appellate authority designated by rule or regulation; and
then take any further appeal allowed by the Administrative Procedure Act.

section.text: The Director of the Administration shall adopt regulations to carry out the provisions of this subtitle.
This subtitle may be cited as the “Maryland Adoption Subsidy Act”.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administration” means the Social Services Administration of the Department.
“Adoption assistance state” means the state that is signatory to an adoption assistance agreement in a particular case.
“Residence state” means the state where the child lives.
The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: locating adoptive families for children who are eligible to receive State assistance and assuring the protection of the interests of the children affected during the entire assistance period requires special measures when the adoptive parents move to other states or are residents of another state; and
providing medical and other necessary services for children, with State assistance, is more difficult when the services are provided in other states.

subsection.text: The purposes of this subtitle are to:

paragraph.text: authorize the Administration to enter into interstate agreements with agencies of other states for the protection of children on whose behalf adoption assistance is being provided; and
provide procedures for interstate adoption assistance payments, including medical payments.

subsection.text: The Administration may develop, participate in the development of, negotiate, and enter into one or more interstate compacts on behalf of this State with other states to implement one or more of the purposes of this subtitle.
When entered into, and for so long as it shall remain in force, the compact shall have the force and effect of law.
A compact entered into pursuant to § 5-4A-03 of this subtitle shall include:

paragraph.text: a provision making the compact available for joinder by all states;
a provision for withdrawal from the compact upon written notice to the parties, but with a period of 1 year between the date of the notice and the effective date of the withdrawal;

a requirement that the protection afforded by or pursuant to the compact continue in force for the duration of the adoption assistance and be applicable to all children and their adoptive parents who on the effective date of the withdrawal are receiving adoption assistance from a party state other than the one in which they are residents and have their principal place of abode; and

a requirement that each instance of adoption assistance to which the compact applies be covered by an adoption assistance agreement in writing between the adoptive parents and the state child welfare agency of the state which undertakes to provide the adoption assistance and that the adoption assistance agreement be expressly for the benefit of the adopted child and enforceable by both the adoptive parents and the state agency providing the adoption assistance.

subsection.text: A compact entered into pursuant to § 5-4A-03 of this subtitle may include a provision establishing procedures and entitlements to medical or other necessary social services for the child in accordance with applicable laws even though the child and the adoptive parents are in a state other than the state responsible for providing the services or the funds to defray part or all of the costs.

paragraph.text: A child with special needs who resides in this State and who is the subject of an adoption assistance agreement with another state shall be entitled to receive a medical assistance identification from this State upon filing with the Administration a certified copy of the adoption assistance agreement obtained from the adoption assistance state which certifies to the eligibility of the child for medical assistance.
The adoptive parents shall be required at least annually to show that the adoption assistance agreement is still in force or has been renewed.

subsection.text: The Administration shall consider the holder of a medical assistance identification pursuant to this section the same as any other holder of a medical assistance identification under the laws of this State and shall process and make payment on claims on account of the holder in the same manner and pursuant to the same conditions and procedures as for other recipients of medical assistance.

paragraph.text: This section shall apply only to medical assistance for children under adoption assistance agreements from states that provide medical assistance to children with special needs under adoption assistance agreements made by this State.

All other children entitled to medical assistance pursuant to adoption assistance agreements entered into by this State shall be eligible to receive it in accordance with the applicable laws and procedures.

section.text: A person who submits a claim for payment or for reimbursement for services or benefits or makes a statement in connection with a claim for payment or reimbursement for services or benefits pursuant to § 5-4A-05 of this subtitle which the person knows or should know is false, misleading, or fraudulent is guilty of perjury and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or both.
The Administration may adopt regulations necessary to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: Consistent with federal law, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene and the Department of Human Resources, in connection with the implementation and execution of this subtitle and any compact entered into pursuant to this subtitle shall include in any State plan made pursuant to the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 (P.L. 96-272), Titles IV-(e) and XIX of the Social Security Act, and any other applicable federal laws, the provision of adoption assistance and medical assistance for which the federal government pays some or all of the cost.
The Departments shall apply for and administer all relevant federal aid in accordance with law.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administration” means the Social Services Administration of the Department.
“Confidential intermediary” means an individual or child placement agency qualified by the Director for the purpose of providing search, contact, and reunion services under this subtitle.
“Director” means the Director of the Administration.
“Member of the adoptive family” means an adoptive parent, grandparent, brother, or sister of an adopted individual.
“Relative” means a parent, brother, sister, child, aunt, or uncle of a biological parent.
“Search, contact, and reunion services” means services:

paragraph.text: to locate adopted individuals, biological parents of adopted individuals, siblings of adopted individuals, and, as provided in § 5–4B–11 of this subtitle, relatives and members of the adoptive family;
to assess the mutual desire for communication or disclosure of information:

subparagraph.text: between adopted individuals and biological parents of adopted individuals;
between adopted individuals and siblings of adopted individuals; and
as provided in § 5–4B–11 of this subtitle, between:

sub-subparagraph.text: adopted individuals and relatives; and
biological parents and members of the adoptive family;

paragraph.text: to provide, or provide referral to, counseling for adopted individuals, biological parents of adopted individuals, siblings of adopted individuals, relatives, and members of the adoptive family; and

if siblings of a minor in out–of–home placement were adopted through a local department, to contact the siblings to develop a placement resource or facilitate a family connection with the siblings of the minor.

subsection.text: “Sibling” means a brother or sister of the whole or half blood who:

paragraph.text: is at least 21 years old; and
has been adopted.
An adopted individual at least 21 years old may apply to the Director to receive search, contact, and reunion services.
If an adopted individual is at least 21 years old, the following individuals may apply to the Director to receive search, contact, and reunion services:

subparagraph.text: a biological parent of the adopted individual;
a sibling of the adopted individual; and
a director of a local department acting on behalf of a minor in out–of–home placement.

subsection.text: An individual who applies to the Director to receive search, contact, and reunion services shall supply any proof of identity or other relevant information required by the Director.

paragraph.text: The Director may establish a reasonable fee for the application for search, contact, and reunion services.
The overall amount of fees collected may not exceed the costs of processing the applications.

subsection.text: A parent who has had his or her parental rights terminated under Subtitle 3 of this title may not apply to receive search, contact, and reunion services under this subtitle.
The Director shall maintain a list of confidential intermediaries.
To qualify to be a confidential intermediary, an applicant shall meet the requirements of subsection (d) of this section.
If the applicant is a child placement agency, the agency shall appoint an employee of the agency as the representative member to make the application on behalf of the agency.

paragraph.text: If the applicant is an individual, the applicant shall:

subparagraph.text: have completed at least 8 hours of training, approved by the Director, in providing search, contact, and reunion services; and
meet any other qualifications that the Director establishes for confidential intermediaries.

paragraph.text: If the applicant is a child placement agency, each employee who will provide search, contact, and reunion services under this subtitle shall:

subparagraph.text: have completed at least 8 hours of training, approved by the Director, in providing search, contact, and reunion services; and
meet any other qualifications that the Director establishes for confidential intermediaries.

paragraph.text: The Director may establish a reasonable fee for an application under this section.
The overall amount of fees collected may not exceed the costs of processing the applications.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the Director shall provide the list of confidential intermediaries to an individual who applies for search, contact, and reunion services.
The Director shall refer an individual who applies for search, contact, and reunion services to the child placement agency that placed the child for adoption if:

paragraph.text: the identity of the child placement agency that placed the child for adoption is known; and
the child placement agency is a confidential intermediary, as defined in § 5-4B-01 of this subtitle.

If the identity of the child placement agency that placed the child for adoption is unknown, the Director shall make reasonable efforts to determine the identity of the child placement agency that placed the child for adoption.

For purposes of paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Director shall have access to any information that is contained in a birth record or public record described in § 5-4B-06(b)(1) or (c)(1) of this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: The Director may charge an individual who applies for search, contact, and reunion services a reasonable fee for a search conducted in accordance with paragraph (2) of this subsection.
The overall amount of fees collected may not exceed the costs of providing the search.

paragraph.text: The Director shall forward any information obtained from a search conducted in accordance with paragraph (2) of this subsection to the confidential intermediary for purposes of providing search, contact, and reunion services.

subsection.text: An individual who applies for search, contact, and reunion services shall execute a written agreement with a confidential intermediary concerning the provision of search, contact, and reunion services.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the confidential intermediary may charge the individual a reasonable fee for search, contact, and reunion services.
The overall amount of fees collected may not exceed the costs of providing the services.

paragraph.text: The confidential intermediary may not charge a director of a local department who applies for search, contact, and reunion services on behalf of a minor in out–of–home placement the fee described in paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: The confidential intermediary shall promptly:

paragraph.text: file the executed agreement with the Director; and
attempt to contact the adopted individual, the biological parent, or the sibling sought by the applicant.

subsection.text: The Director or the Adoption Program Manager of the Department may authorize a confidential intermediary to obtain information described in subsection (b) or (c) of this section to locate an individual sought by an applicant.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a confidential intermediary may apply to the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene for a copy of the following:

subparagraph.text: the original certificate of birth and any records that relate to the new certificate of birth of an adopted individual;
the new certificate of birth that was substituted for the original certificate of birth of an adopted individual under § 4-211 of the Health - General Article; and
the report of the decree or judgment of adoption filed by the clerk of the court under § 4-211 of the Health - General Article.

paragraph.text: To apply for a copy of a record listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection, a confidential intermediary shall submit to the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene a written statement signed by the Director or the Adoption Program Manager of the Department and witnessed by a notary public that authorizes the confidential intermediary to obtain information necessary to locate an individual sought by an applicant.

If a confidential intermediary complies with paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene shall give a copy of a record requested under this subsection that is on file with the Secretary to the confidential intermediary.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a confidential intermediary may access any information that is contained in a public record, as defined in § 10-611 of the State Government Article, including a court record.

To have access to information contained in a public record, a confidential intermediary shall submit to the custodian of a public record a written statement signed by the Director or the Adoption Program Manager of the Department and witnessed by a notary public that authorizes the confidential intermediary to obtain information necessary to locate an individual sought by an applicant.
If a confidential intermediary complies with paragraph (2) of this subsection, a custodian shall permit inspection of a public record requested under this subsection by the confidential intermediary.

subsection.text: Within 90 days after executing a search, contact, and reunion services agreement under § 5-4B-05 or § 5-4B-11 of this subtitle, a confidential intermediary shall file a report with the Director stating that:

paragraph.text: the individual contacted by the confidential intermediary consents to the disclosure of specified information;
the individual contacted by the confidential intermediary does not consent to the disclosure of any information;
the individual sought by the confidential intermediary has not been located; or
the individual sought by the confidential intermediary is deceased.

subsection.text: If the individual sought by the confidential intermediary is deceased, the confidential intermediary shall indicate in the report whether any relatives or members of the adoptive family were contacted, as provided in § 5-4B-11 of this subtitle, and whether those individuals consent to the disclosure of information.
The report and any documents filed in accordance with this section are confidential.

paragraph.text: If an individual contacted by a confidential intermediary consents to the disclosure of any information, the confidential intermediary shall obtain the written consent of the individual witnessed by a notary public.
The written consent shall specify the nature of the information to be disclosed.

If a confidential intermediary obtains written consent under subsection (a) of this section, the confidential intermediary shall disclose the information specified in the consent to the individual who applied for search, contact, and reunion services.
The confidential intermediary shall disclose only the information that has been authorized by the written consent.

section.text: If an individual contacted by a confidential intermediary does not consent to the disclosure of any information, the confidential intermediary:

paragraph.text: may not disclose any information concerning the individual contacted;
shall refrain from further and subsequent inquiry with the individual contacted; and
shall report the refusal to the individual who applied for search, contact, and reunion services.

subsection.text: If a confidential intermediary files a report under § 5-4B-07 of this subtitle stating that an individual sought has not been located, the confidential intermediary shall continue to make reasonable attempts to contact the individual sought for the period specified in the search, contact, and reunion services agreement executed in accordance with § 5-4B-05 or § 5-4B-11 of this subtitle.

If the confidential intermediary is unsuccessful at locating the individual sought within the period specified in the search, contact, and reunion services agreement, the confidential intermediary shall file a report with the Director stating the failure to locate the individual sought.

If an individual sought by a confidential intermediary is deceased, the confidential intermediary may not disclose the identity of the deceased to the individual who applied for search, contact, and reunion services.
The confidential intermediary shall report the fact that the individual sought is deceased to the individual who applied for search, contact, and reunion services.

paragraph.text: If the deceased individual is a biological parent, the confidential intermediary may, with the consent of the applicant, attempt to contact a relative who is at least 21 years old to assess the willingness of the relative to communicate or exchange information with the applicant.

If the deceased individual is an adopted individual, the confidential intermediary may, with the consent of the applicant, attempt to contact a member of the adoptive family who is at least 21 years old to assess the willingness of the member of the adoptive family to communicate or exchange information with the applicant.

If the applicant consents to contacting a relative or member of the adoptive family, the applicant shall execute another written agreement with the confidential intermediary concerning the provision of search, contact, and reunion services under this subsection.

sub-subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the confidential intermediary may charge the individual a reasonable fee for the additional search, contact, and reunion services described in this subsection.
The overall amount of fees collected may not exceed the costs of providing the services.

subparagraph.text: The confidential intermediary may not charge a director of a local department who applies for search, contact, and reunion services on behalf of a minor in out–of–home placement the fee described in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph.

paragraph.text: The confidential intermediary shall promptly:

subparagraph.text: file the executed agreement with the Director; and
attempt to contact the relative or member of the adoptive family sought by the applicant.

paragraph.text: The provisions of this subtitle shall apply to search, contact, and reunion services provided by a confidential intermediary under this subsection.

section.text: The Director shall adopt regulations to implement the provisions of this subtitle, including regulations concerning:

paragraph.text: the application process for search, contact, and reunion services;
qualifications for a confidential intermediary;
the agreement for search, contact, and reunion services executed by a confidential intermediary and an adopted individual, biological parent, or sibling; and
the delivery and scope of search, contact, and reunion services.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administration” means the Social Services Administration of the Department.
“Adoptee” means an individual:

paragraph.text: who was adopted in this State; or
who was placed for adoption by:

subparagraph.text: a child placement agency licensed in this State; or
a local department.

subsection.text: “Director” means the Director of the Administration.
“Identifying information” means information that reveals the identity or location of an adoptee, the natural parents of an adoptee, or a natural sibling.
Repealed.
“Natural father” means a man who:

paragraph.text: was married to the adoptee’s natural mother at the time of conception;
was married to the adoptee’s natural mother at the time of the adoptee’s birth;
was named as the father on the adoptee’s pre-adoption birth certificate, unless the man has signed a denial of paternity or his nonpaternity has been determined by a court;
was identified by the natural mother as the father of the adoptee, unless the man has signed a denial of paternity or his nonpaternity has been determined by a court;
has been adjudicated to be the father of the adoptee; or
has acknowledged himself orally or in writing to be the father of the adoptee.

subsection.text: “Natural sibling” means an individual who is at least 21 years old and shares 1 or both natural parents with an adoptee.
“Registry” means the Mutual Consent Voluntary Adoption Registry.

section.text: The purpose of this subtitle is to:

paragraph.text: establish within the Administration a Mutual Consent Voluntary Adoption Registry where natural parents, adoptees, and natural siblings may register if they wish to have identifying information released to each other; and
provide for the disclosure of identifying information to natural parents, adoptees, and natural siblings who have registered with the Mutual Consent Voluntary Adoption Registry.

subsection.text: The Director shall:

paragraph.text: establish and maintain a Mutual Consent Voluntary Adoption Registry;
adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this subtitle; and
set and assess a reasonable fee for registrants, except that an individual may not be denied registration solely because of an inability to pay the fee.

subsection.text: The Director may contract with child placement agencies in this State to perform specific duties under this subtitle.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, or pursuant to a court order, the Administration may not disclose information contained in the Registry.

The Administration shall retain affidavits and other information collected concerning a registrant until the date specified by the registrant, or for 99 years after the date of registration, whichever occurs first.

section.text: Only the following individuals may register with the Registry:

paragraph.text: an adoptee:

subparagraph.text: who is at least 21 years of age; and
who does not have a natural sibling under the age of 21 years who has the same adoptive parents;

paragraph.text: a natural mother;
a natural father; and
a natural sibling.
To register with the Registry, an individual shall submit a notarized affidavit containing the following information:

subparagraph.text: the individual’s current name and any previous name by which the individual was known;
the individual’s address and telephone number;
if the individual is a natural parent of the adoptee, the original and adopted names, if known, of the adoptee;
if the individual is an adoptee who is seeking information regarding the adoptee’s natural parents, any names, if known, by which the natural parents are or were known;
if the individual is an adoptee who is seeking information regarding a natural sibling, any names, if known, by which the natural sibling is or was known;
if known, the place and date of birth of the adoptee;
if known, the name and address of the child placement agency, if any, that placed the adoptee;
if known, the names of the adoptive parents of the adoptee;
the name and address of the court that issued the adoption or guardianship order; and
a statement of the individual’s consent to be identified to other registrants.

paragraph.text: A registrant shall notify the Administration of changes in information occurring after the affidavit is filed.
A registrant may withdraw from the Registry at any time by submitting a notarized affidavit to that effect to the Administration.
The Administration shall obtain information necessary for identifying an adoptee, a natural mother of an adoptee, a natural father, or a natural sibling.
The Administration may not obtain information regarding:

subparagraph.text: the adoptive parents of the adoptee;
a child of the adoptive parents who is not a natural sibling; or
the financial status of the adoptive parents of the adoptee.

subsection.text: On receipt of an affidavit, the Administration shall:

paragraph.text: attempt to match registrants or to provide matching information; and
if a match is made, direct the child placement agency, if known, or the local department, if there is no known child placement agency, to notify the registrants through a confidential contact.
Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, a match is made when:

subparagraph.text: an adoptee and the adoptee’s natural mother and natural father register; or
2 or more natural siblings register.

paragraph.text: A match is made when an adoptee and only 1 natural parent of the adoptee register if:

subparagraph.text: notice of the filing of the petition for adoption or guardianship was given to the nonregistering parent and the parent did not participate in the judicial proceedings that terminated the parent-child relationship or declared the parent-child relationship was nonexistent;
an adoptee and the natural mother of the adoptee register and there is no known natural father;

the natural mother of the adoptee, or in the case of an agency adoption, the agency submits, or the Administration obtains from a court of competent jurisdiction in the state of the adoptee’s birth or adoption, a copy of a judgment that declares that the identity of the natural father is unknown;
the Administration has information that indicates that the other natural parent is dead;
notice of the filing of the petition for adoption or guardianship was not given to the nonregistering natural parent of the adoptee; or

1 year has elapsed since the registering natural parent filed the affidavit and the nonregistering natural parent has not filed a notarized affidavit stating the nonregistering parent’s refusal to permit the match.

paragraph.text: Matching information is provided:

subparagraph.text: if both natural parents are deceased; and
if only an adoptee has registered.

paragraph.text: In order to make a match or provide matching information, the Administration may inquire into the records of a child placement agency or court that issued an adoption or guardianship order.

The court that issued the adoption order shall order that the Administration have access to court records on receipt of a petition from the Administration that states that review of the records is needed in order to make a match or to provide matching information under this section.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administration” means:

paragraph.text: the Social Services Administration of the Department; or
any other unit within the Department to which the Secretary of Human Resources has delegated in writing specified responsibilities of the Administration under this subtitle.

subsection.text: “Child care provider” means the adult who has primary responsibility for the operation of a family child care home or large family child care home.

“Family child care” means the care given to a child under the age of 13 years or to any developmentally disabled person under the age of 21 years, in place of parental care for less than 24 hours a day, in a residence other than the child’s residence, for which the child care provider is paid.
“Family child care home” means a residence in which family child care is provided for up to 8 children.
“Foster care” means continuous 24–hour care and supportive services provided for a minor child placed by a child placement agency in an approved family home.
“Group care” means continuous 24–hour care and supportive services provided for a minor child placed in a licensed group facility.

“Kinship care” means continuous 24–hour care and supportive services provided for a minor child placed by a child placement agency in the home of a relative related by blood or marriage within the 5th degree of consanguinity or affinity under the civil law rule.
“Large family child care home” means a residence in which family child care is provided for at least 9 but not more than 12 children.

paragraph.text: “License” means a license issued by the Administration under this subtitle.
“License” includes:

subparagraph.text: a child placement agency license;
a child care home license;
a child care institution license; and
a residential educational facility license.

subsection.text: “Local board” means a local citizen board of review for children in out–of–home care.
“Out–of–home care” means:

paragraph.text: out–of–home placement; and
the monitoring of and services provided to a child in aftercare following a child’s out–of–home placement.

subsection.text: “Out–of–home placement” means placement of a child into foster care, kinship care, group care, or residential treatment care.
“Residential educational facility” means:

paragraph.text: a facility that:

subparagraph.text: provides special education and related services for students with disabilities;
holds a certificate of approval issued by the State Board of Education; and
provides continuous 24–hour care and supportive services to children in a residential setting; or

paragraph.text: one of the following schools:

subparagraph.text: the Benedictine School;
the Linwood School;
the Maryland School for the Blind; or
the Maryland School for the Deaf.

subsection.text: “Residential treatment care” means continuous 24–hour care and supportive services for a minor child placed in a facility that provides formal programs of basic care, social work, and health care services.
“State Board” means the State Citizens Review Board for Children.
“Unregistered family child care home” means a residence in which family child care is provided and in which the child care provider:

paragraph.text: has not obtained a certificate of registration from the State Department of Education;
is not related by blood or marriage to each child in the provider’s care;
is not a friend of each child’s parents or legal guardian and is providing care on a regular basis; and
has not received the care of the child from a child placement agency licensed by the Administration or by a local department.

subsection.text: “Voluntary placement agreement” means a binding, written agreement voluntarily entered into between a local department and the parent or legal guardian of a minor child that specifies, at a minimum, the legal status of the child and the rights and obligations of the parent or legal guardian, the child, and the local department while the child is in placement.
The General Assembly declares that:

paragraph.text: minor children are not capable of protecting themselves; and
when a parent has relinquished the care of the parent’s minor child to others, there is a possibility of certain risks to the child that require compensating measures.

subsection.text: It is the policy of this State:

paragraph.text: to protect minor children whose care has been relinquished to others by the children’s parent;
to resolve doubts in favor of the child when there is a conflict between the interests of a minor child and the interests of an adult; and
